    73. 73
      Glarum, S. H. J. Chem. Phys. 1960, 33, 1371
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      73
      Dielectric relaxation of polar liquids
      Glarum, Sivert H.
      Journal of Chemical Physics (1960), 33 (), 1371-5CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
      The statistical theory of the dielec. relaxation of polar liquids is developed by using the fluctuation-dissipation approach to linear dissipative phenomena, and an expression is derived relating the complex dielec. const. to a time-dependent microscopic correlation function. A finite no. of microscopic relaxation times leads to an equal no. of macroscopic decay times, and, in the case of a single relaxation time τ0, the decay time is given by T0 = [3 ε0/(2 ε0 + ε∞)]τ0, where ε0 is the static dielec, const. and ε∞ is the high-frequency dielec. const. Relaxation times were also detd. for systems having 2 decay times, and for systems characterized by circular-arc and skewed-arc distribution functions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3MXmt1yjsA%253D%253D&md5=6392929b6e48a507512825460f6ef710
    74. 74
      Bordewijk, P. Chem. Phys. Lett. 1975, 32, 592
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      74
      Defect-diffusion models of dielectric relaxation
      Bordewijk, P.
      Chemical Physics Letters (1975), 32 (3), 592-6CODEN: CHPLBC; ISSN:0009-2614.
      Dielec. relaxation due to defect-diffusion in liqs., as introduced by Glarum (1960), is considered for the case that reorientation of a mol. at time t >0 may be due not only to the nearest defect at t = 0, but to any defect in the liq. For 1-dimensional diffusion one then obtains the empirical relaxation function introduced by Williams and Watts (1970) with β = 0.5, and for 3-dimensional diffusion a result only slightly differing from that for a single relaxation time. A model of dielec. relaxation by diffusion of defects only leads to considerable deviations from a single relaxation time when the diffusion is restricted in some way.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2MXks12rt7g%253D&md5=f30c387a821900ddddf7f7073ad46cff
    75. 75
      Shlesinger, M. F.; Montroll, E. W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1984, 81, 1280
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      On the Williams-Watts function of dielectric relaxation
      Shlesinger, Michael F.; Montroll, Elliott W.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1984), 81 (4), 1280-3CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      Exptl. frequency-dependent dielec. consts. of broad classes of materials including polymeric systems and glasses may be interpreted in terms of the Williams-Watts polarization decay function .vphi.α(t) = exp[-(t/T)α], 0 < α < 1. The exponent α and the time const. T depend on the material and fixed external conditions such as temp. and pressure. The authors derive this form of .vphi.α(t)from the following random-walk model. Suppose that an elec. field has been applied for some time to a medium contg. many polar mols. (or polar groups in complex mols.) and the direction of their dipole moments remains frozen as the field is removed. Further, suppose that the medium contains mobile defects that on reaching the site of a frozen dipole relax the medium to the degree that the dipole may reorient itself. If the diffusion of defects toward dipoles is executed as a continuous-time random walk composed of an alternation of steps and pauses and the pausing-time distribution function has a long tail of the form ψ(t) .varies. t-1-α, then the relaxation function has the above fractional exponential form.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXhsV2gtbc%253D&md5=3d2960df0db50c248bd23a96d6d628dd
    76. 76
      Fletcher, A. J.; Cussen, E. J.; Bradshaw, D.; Rosseinsky, M. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 9750
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      76
      Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Nanoporous Ni2(4,4'-Bipyridine)3(NO3)4 Metal-Organic Framework Materials Templated with Methanol and Ethanol: Structural Effects in Adsorption Kinetics
      Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Cussen, Edmund J.; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (31), 9750-9759CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Desolvation of Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4·2CH3OH and Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4·2C2H5OH give flexible metal-org. porous structures M and E, resp., which have the same stoichiometry, but subtly different structures. This study combines measurements of the thermodn. and kinetics of carbon dioxide, methanol, and ethanol sorption on adsorbents M and E over a range of temps. with adsorbent structural characterization at different adsorbate (guest) loadings. The adsorption kinetics for methanol and ethanol adsorption on porous structure E obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for adsorption at low surface coverage. The corresponding adsorption kinetics for porous structure M follow a double exponential (DE) model, which is consistent with two different barriers for diffusion through the windows and along the pores in the structure. The former is a high-energy barrier due to the opening of the windows in the structure, required to allow adsorption to occur, while the latter is a lower-energy barrier for diffusion in the pore cavities. X-ray diffraction studies at various methanol and ethanol loadings showed that the host porous structures E and M underwent different scissoring motions, leading to an increase in unit cell vol. with the space group remaining unchanged during adsorption. The results are discussed in terms of reversible adsorbate/adsorbent (host/guest) structural changes and the adsorption mechanism involving hydrogen-bonding interactions with sp. surface sites for methanol and ethanol adsorption in relation to pore size and extent of filling. This paper contains the first evidence for individual kinetic barriers to diffusion through windows and pore cavities in flexible porous coordination polymer frameworks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXlvVSktrs%253D&md5=8411f5a8659801221ba73a7b0b76df57
    77. 77
      Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. C 2007, 111, 2107
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      77
      Kinetic Isotope Quantum Effects in the Adsorption of H2O and D2O on Porous Carbons
      Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2007), 111 (5), 2107-2115CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      This paper describes a study of the adsorption characteristics of H2O and D2O on 2 activated carbons, BAX950, contg. a range of micro- and mesoporosity, and G209, a predominantly microporous material. Adsorption kinetics of H2O and D2O on activated C BAX950 were studied at 293-313 K and 278-303 K, resp. The adsorption/desorption of H2O and D2O were also studied on activated C G209 at 298 K. The adsorption isotherms for H2O and D2O agree well while greater adsorption hysteresis was obsd. for H2O compared with D2O. Comparison of the adsorption kinetic behavior of H2O and D2O indicated a kinetic isotope effect. The trends in isotherm hysteresis, kinetic parameters, and activation energies are attributed to quantum effects, which are the source of differences in intermol. hydrogen bonding in H2O and D2O adsorbates and bonding between these adsorbates and surface oxygen functional groups. The effects of confinement in pores on adsorbate structure are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXktV2qug%253D%253D&md5=5fb83363787135e860e810925d6423ac

      Fletcher, A. J.; Yuzak, Y.; Thomas, K. M. Carbon 2006, 44, 989
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      78
      Adsorption and desorption kinetics for hydrophilic and hydrophobic vapors on activated carbon
      Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Yuezak, Yaprak; Thomas, K. Mark
      Carbon (2006), 44 (5), 989-1004CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Adsorption dynamics are of fundamental importance in applications of adsorbents in real situations. The adsorption/desorption characteristics of a series of adsorbates, with varying hydrophilic/hydrophobic and structural characteristics, for activated C BAX950, were investigated for temps. in the range 288-323 K. These data provide a comprehensive kinetic study of adsorption/desorption for an activated C. The results are discussed in relation to the adsorbent pore structure and functional group concn., adsorptive structure and adsorption mechanism. The study provides evidence for a compensation effect where activation energy and ln(pre-exponential factor) parameters obtained from the Arrhenius equation exhibit a linear correlation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvVensQ%253D%253D&md5=252f7312623d74ff9bf55dca001fae30

      Bell, J. G.; Zhao, X.; Uygur, Y.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. C 2011, 115, 2776
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      79
      Adsorption of Chloroaromatic Models for Dioxins on Porous Carbons: The Influence of Adsorbate Structure and Surface Functional Groups on Surface Interactions and Adsorption Kinetics
      Bell, Jon G.; Zhao, Xuebo; Uygur, Yaprak; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2011), 115 (6), 2776-2789CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxin and polychlorinated dibenzofuran species are classes of extremely toxic compds. generated in very low concns. in postcombustion gases and these may be removed by adsorption on porous carbons. Their extreme toxicity and very low volatility prevent detailed study of their adsorption characteristics, and therefore, models for dioxins were used. Chlorobenzene, 2-chlorotoluene, 1,3-dichlorobenzene, and 2-chloroanisole were used as models to study factors influencing the adsorption characteristics of dioxins on porous carbons. Adsorption studies were carried out under conditions of very low concn. and temps. up to 453 K, which simulate those found in dioxin abatement systems. Adsorption of 2-chloroanisole on three carbons with various micro/mesoporous structures showed that microporous structure was a crit. adsorbent characteristic under these conditions. A microporous activated carbon was selected for detailed thermodn. and kinetic studies of adsorption of chloroarom. species in relation to adsorbate structure and adsorbent surface functional groups. Virial equation anal. of adsorption isotherms was used to det. the Henry's Law consts. and isosteric enthalpies of adsorption at zero surface coverage to compare adsorbate-adsorbent interactions. The van't Hoff equation was used to det. the enthalpy of adsorption as a function of surface coverage. The role of surface functional groups on adsorption thermodn. was studied by oxidizing and reducing the carbon in nitric acid and hydrogen, resp. The important factor influencing adsorption at very low concns. is the adsorbate adsorbent interaction. Oxidn. of the carbon adsorbent only has a small effect on the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. The adsorption kinetics for each isotherm pressure increment were described by the stretched exponential equation. The activation energies and enthalpies of activation were calcd. as a function of surface coverage for adsorption kinetics of chloroarom. species. The planar mols. studied had lower activation energies and enthalpies of activation than isosteric enthalpy of adsorption indicating that a site-to-site surface hopping mechanism is the main factor in detg. the adsorption kinetics. In comparison, 2-chloroanisole is nonplanar with a methoxy group giving rise to a larger min. cross-section size and higher barrier to diffusion than isosteric enthalpy of adsorption at low surface coverage leading to the adsorption kinetics being mainly detd. by diffusion through constrictions in the porous structure under these conditions. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption initially increase with increasing surface coverage and this is attributed to π-π interactions of planar arom. mols. confined in microporosity. The trends in the kinetic barriers and isosteric enthalpies of adsorption with surface coverage for 2-chlorotoluene are similar irresp. of adsorbent oxidn./redn., indicating that surface functional groups only have a relatively small effect on adsorption characteristics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1egurc%253D&md5=6d300db5104b9b0fad7b84271bdcb133
    80. 80
      Zhao, X.; Villar-Rodil, S.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. B 2006, 110, 9947
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      80
      Kinetic Isotope Effect for H2 and D2 Quantum Molecular Sieving in Adsorption/Desorption on Porous Carbon Materials
      Zhao, Xuebo; Villar-Rodil, Silvia; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2006), 110 (20), 9947-9955CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
      Adsorption and desorption of H2 and D2 from porous C materials, such as activated C at 77 K, are usually fully reversible with very rapid adsorption/desorption kinetics. The adsorption and desorption of H2 and D2 at 77 K on a C mol. sieve (Takeda 3A), where the kinetic selectivity was incorporated by C deposition, and a C, where the pore structure was modified by thermal annealing to give similar pore structure characteristics to the C mol. sieve substrate, were studied. The D2 adsorption and desorption kinetics were significantly faster (up to ×1.9) than the corresponding H2 kinetics for specific pressure increments/decrements. This represents the 1st exptl. observation of kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving in porous materials due to the larger zero-point energy for the lighter H2, resulting in slower adsorption/desorption kinetics compared with the heavier D2. The results are discussed in terms of the adsorption mechanism.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XktVertbw%253D&md5=08b52fe90cfa35318807cca2a2935675
    81. 81
      Fletcher, A. J.; Cussen, E. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J.; Kepert, C. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 10001
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Adsorption Dynamics of Gases and Vapors on the Nanoporous Metal Organic Framework Material Ni2(4,4'-Bipyridine)3(NO3)4: Guest Modification of Host Sorption Behavior
      Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Cussen, Edmund J.; Prior, Timothy J.; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.; Kepert, Cameron J.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (41), 10001-10011CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      This study combines measurements of the thermodn. and kinetics of guest sorption with powder x-ray diffraction measurements of the nanoporous metal org. framework adsorbent (host) at different adsorptive (guest) loadings. The adsorption characteristics of nitrogen, Ar, CO2, nitrous oxide and EtOH and MeOH vapors on Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4 were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure. Isotherm steps were obsd. for both CO2 and nitrous oxide adsorption at ∼10-20% of the total pore vol. and at ∼70% of total pore vol. for MeOH adsorption. The adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for adsorption at low surface coverage. At high surface coverage, both MeOH and EtOH adsorption follow a combined barrier resistance/diffusion model. The rates of adsorption in the region of both the CO2 and MeOH isotherm steps were significantly slower than those obsd. either before or after the step. X-ray diffraction studies at various MeOH loadings showed that the host structure disordered initially but underwent a structural change in the region of the isotherm step. These isotherm steps are ascribed to discrete structural changes in the host adsorbent that are induced by adsorption on different sites. Isotherm steps were not obsd. for EtOH adsorption, which followed a Langmuir isotherm. Previous x-ray crystallog. studies showed that all the sites are equiv. for EtOH adsorption on Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4, with the host structure undergoing a scissoring motion and the space group remaining unchanged during adsorption. The activation energies and preexponential factors for MeOH and EtOH adsorption were calcd. for each pressure increment at which the linear driving force model was obeyed. There was a good correlation between activation energy and ln(preexponential factor), indicating a compensation effect. The results are discussed in terms of reversible adsorbate/adsorbent (guest/host) structural changes and interactions and the adsorption mechanism. The paper contains the 1st evidence of specific interactions between guests and functional groups leading to structural change in flexible porous coordination polymer frameworks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXmvFGltrg%253D&md5=da99d0d8723aa100d67c46259387508a

      LeVan, M. D. In Adsorption Science and Technology, NATO ASI Series E Applied Science; Rodriguez, A. E.; LeVan, M. D., Eds.; Kluwer: Dordrecht, The Netherlands, 1989; Vol. 158, p 149.

      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    83. 83
      Zhao, Z. X.; Li, Z.; Lin, Y. S. Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2009, 48, 10015
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      83
      Adsorption and Diffusion of Carbon Dioxide on Metal-Organic Framework (MOF-5)
      Zhao, Zhenxia; Li, Zhong; Lin, Y. S.
      Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2009), 48 (22), 10015-10020CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
      Adsorption equil. and diffusion of CO2 on microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOF-5, or IRMOF-1) crystals were exptl. studied by the gravimetric method in the pressure range up to 1 atm. The MOF-5 crystal cubes of about 40-60 μm in sizes were synthesized by the solvothermal method. Freundlich adsorption isotherm equation can fit well CO2 adsorption isotherms on MOF-5, with isosteric heat of adsorption of about 34 kJ/mol. Diffusion coeff. of CO2 in the MOF-5 is in the range of 8.1-11.5 × 10-9 cm2/s in 295-331K with activation energy of 7.61 kJ/mol. MOF-5 offers attractive adsorption properties as an adsorbent for sepn. of CO2 from flue gas.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFajsrrO&md5=d0e3634b7965ffc018e2aa933e8ca5d9
    84. 84
      Sabouni, R.; Kazemian, H.; Rohani, S. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2013, 175, 85
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      84
      Carbon dioxide adsorption in microwave-synthesized metal organic framework CPM-5: Equilibrium and kinetics study
      Sabouni, Rana; Kazemian, Hossein; Rohani, Sohrab
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2013), 175 (), 85-91CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      The adsorption equil. and diffusion of CO2 in CPM-5 (cryst. porous materials) were exptl. studied using a volumetric approach at three different temps. 273, 298, and 318 K and gas pressures up to 105 kPa. The Freundlich adsorption equil. model was applied to correlate the adsorption isotherms, and the classical microspore diffusion model was applied to obtain the adsorption kinetic curves and diffusivity of CO2 in CPM-5. The selectivity of CO2 over N2 was estd. from the single component isotherms at conditions relevant to post combustion applications (0.15 bar PCO2 and 0.75 bar pN2). At pressures up to 105 kPa, the CPM-5 adsorbent has CO2 adsorption capacity of 3 mmol/g, 2.3 mmol/g, at 273 K and 298 K, resp., which is significantly higher than those of MOF-5 under the same conditions. The selectivity factor was 14.2 and 16.1 at 273 and 298 K, resp. The CO2 diffusivity in CPM-5, estd. from the adsorption kinetic data measured at low pressures, are 1.86 × 10-12 m2/s, 7.04 × 10-12 m2/s, and 7.87 × 10-12m2/s at 273 K, 298 K and 318 K, resp. The initial isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 on the CPM-5 is 36.1 kJ/mol. CPM-5 shows attractive adsorption properties as an adsorbent for sepn. of CO2 from flue gas.

      Novel MOF-Membrane for Molecular Sieving Predicted by IR-Diffusion Studies and Molecular Modeling
      Bux, Helge; Chmelik, Christian; van Baten, Jasper M.; Krishna, Rajamani; Caro, Juergen
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2010), 22 (42), 4741-4743CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      This paper reports a combination of a theor. and an exptl. method to est. the carbon dioxide/methane permeation selectivity of a ZIF-8 mol. sieve membrane. The results fit remarkably well with the exptl. values. This findings might indicate that the pore apertures are rather flexible than rigid.

      Chmelik, C.; van Baten, J.; Krishna, R. J. Membr. Sci. 2012, 397, 87
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      86
      Hindering effects in diffusion of CO2/CH4 mixtures in ZIF-8 crystals
      Chmelik, Christian; van Baten, Jasper; Krishna, Rajamani
      Journal of Membrane Science (2012), 397-398 (), 87-91CODEN: JMESDO; ISSN:0376-7388. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Cage-type micro-porous materials such as LTA, CHA, SAPO-34, DDR, ERI, ZIF-7, and ZIF-8 have significant potential for use in membrane technologies for CO2 capture. The permeation selectivities are governed by a combination of adsorption and diffusion selectivities, each of which can be sep. manipulated. In this study we have investigated the characteristics of CO2/CH4 mixt. diffusion in ZIF-8 by monitoring the uptake within crystals using infra-red microscopy (IRM). The uptake profiles were fitted to det. the "effective" Fick diffusivities of the individual components in the mixt. The diffusivity measurements, conducted for a range of loadings, clearly demonstrate that the preponderance of CO2 at the window regions of ZIF-8 hinders the inter-cage transport of partner CH4 mols. Such hindering effects serve to enhance the CO2/CH4 permeation selectivities across ZIF-8 membranes for high mixt. loadings within the membrane above values anticipated on the basis of unary permeances.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xjt1Wnsbk%253D&md5=3207d6830c01b9a2d0ee344a6b46cb34

      Vidoni, A.; Ruthven, D. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2012, 159, 57
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      87
      Diffusion of methane in DD3R zeolite
      Vidoni, Adam; Ruthven, Douglas
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2012), 159 (), 57-65CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      Diffusion of CH4 in 2 different samples of DDR crystals (one of which had been subjected to a proprietary treatment) was studied exptl. by the ZLC technique. Measurements were made over a wide range of temps. (273-423 K) and purge flow rates. The ZLC response curves for both samples are shown to be consistent with the simple model of intra-cryst. diffusion control with no evidence of any significant surface resistance. The derived equil. consts. and diffusivities are consistent with the limited published data already available for this system. There is a significant difference in both diffusivity and diffusional activation energy between the untreated and treated samples suggesting a somewhat larger free aperture for the windows of the treated sample. For both samples the diffusivity of CH4 is substantially increased in the presence of a CO2 atmosphere; as is to be expected from transition state theory for a competitive adsorption system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XotVahtr8%253D&md5=a68ab477e528e35cdecfe7158d484097

      Binder, T.; Chmelik, C.; Karger, J.; Martinez-Joaristi, A.; Gascon, J.; Kapteijn, F.; Ruthven, D. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2013, 180, 219
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      88
      A diffusion study of small hydrocarbons in DDR zeolites by micro-imaging
      Binder, Tomas; Chmelik, Christian; Karger, Jorg; Martinez-Joaristi, Alberto; Gascon, Jorge; Kapteijn, Freek; Ruthven, Douglas
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2013), 180 (), 219-228CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      Intracryst. diffusion of the light hydrocarbons methane, ethane, ethylene and propylene in three different species of zeolite DDR was studied by recording the transient concn. profiles during uptake and release. The measured profiles approx. the form of the appropriate soln. of the diffusion equation for radial diffusion in an infinite cylinder. This is as expected since, for an ideal DDR crystal with its 2-dimensional pore structure, there should be no flux in the axial direction. Over the range of guest mols. considered, the diffusivities decrease, with increasing crit. mol. diam., over more than three orders of magnitude, i.e. over about one order of magnitude on comparing ethane, ethylene and ethane, and over, addnl., more than two orders of magnitude for propylene. The obsd. diffusivities are in reasonable agreement (with differences of up to a factor of three) between the three different DDR specimens as well as with values from the literature, obtained mainly from transient macroscopic measurement or microscopic PFG NMR self-diffusion measurements. All measurements were performed by the same exptl. technique (micro-imaging by interference microscopy), and the derived diffusivities provide a coherent picture of the diffusion process.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlOrtbbM&md5=5aff6d8581f3bc7ea99e0dec33a97501

      Vidoni, A.; Ruthven, D. M. Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2012, 51, 1383
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      89
      Diffusion of C2H6 and C2H4 in DDR Zeolite
      Vidoni, Adam; Ruthven, Douglas M.
      Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2012), 51 (3), 1383-1390CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
      Diffusion of ethane and ethylene in large crystals of DDR clathrisil (the pure silica analog of ZSM-58) has been studied in detail by the zero length column (ZLC) technique. The behavior of ethane and ethylene is very similar with respect to both kinetics and equil. Measurements were made with two different DDR samples with both He and CO2 as the carrier gas. In contrast to methane neither the equil. nor the diffusivity of ethane (or ethylene) is significantly affected by the presence of CO2, suggesting noncompetitive adsorption. Although the diffusivity of the C2 hydrocarbons is about an order of magnitude smaller than that of methane the activation energies are similar or even smaller. Also, in contrast to the behavior of methane, the data show clear evidence of a small but significant surface resistance (in addn. to the intracryst. diffusional resistance).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1ChtLrP&md5=5432a7fe36179a9319eeda8f91f35ead

      Bleken, B. T. L.; Lillerud, K. P.; Splith, T.; Pusch, A. K.; Stallmach, F. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2013, 182, 25
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      90
      PFG NMR diffusion measurements of CH4 and CO2 through large ZSM-58-crystals
      Bleken, Bjoern-Tore Loenstad; Lillerud, Karl Petter; Splith, Tobias; Pusch, Anne-Kirstin; Stallmach, Frank
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2013), 182 (), 25-31CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      Large crystals of zeolite ZSM-58 having the DDR-topol. have been synthesized. The crystals are diamond shaped and 100-160 μm long. Basic characterization involving X-ray diffraction and N2-porosimetry proved good structure quality and microporosity of the sample. 1H and 13C PFG NMR self-diffusion studies of single gas and binary 1:1 mixts. with CO2 and CH4 show that - in agreement with the topol. of the ZSM-58 - the intracryst. mol. diffusion occurs in a two dimensionally interconnected micropore space. The self-diffusion coeffs. of the smaller carbon dioxide exceed those of the larger methane mols. by about two orders of magnitude, which is clearly the effect of increased diffusional resistance and shape selectivity within the narrow 8-ring window system of the ZSM-58 micropores. Carbon dioxide diffusion is rather const. and methane diffusion increases with increasing total loading. For methane this indicates that the narrow windows act as barriers which are easier passed if addnl. interactions with adsorbed mols. are present. These trends for the loading dependences in both the single-component and the binary mixt. diffusion studies confirm earlier predictions by kinetic MC and MD computer simulations. However, at low loadings the predicted values for methane self-diffusion are significantly smaller than the exptl. NMR data.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFGru77N&md5=cefca1811ac6a67be24a4b813b0982a9

      Deroche, I.; Maurin, G.; Borah, B. J.; Yashonath, S.; Jobic, H. J. Phys. Chem. C 2010, 114, 5027
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      91
      Diffusion of Pure CH4 and Its Binary Mixture with CO2 in Faujasite NaY: A Combination of Neutron Scattering Experiments and Molecular Dynamics Simulations
      Deroche, I.; Maurin, G.; Borah, B. J.; Yashonath, S.; Jobic, H.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2010), 114 (11), 5027-5034CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      The self-diffusion properties of pure CH4 and its binary mixt. with CO2 within NaY zeolite have been investigated by combining an exptl. quasi-elastic neutron scattering (QENS) technique and classical mol. dynamics simulations. The QENS measurements carried out at 200 K led to an unexpected self-diffusivity profile for pure CH4 with the presence of a max. for a loading of 32 CH4/unit cell, which was never obsd. before for the diffusion of apolar species in a zeolite system with large windows. Mol. dynamics simulations were performed using two distinct microscopic models for representing the CH4/NaY interactions. Depending on the model, we are able to fairly reproduce either the magnitude or the profile of the self-diffusivity. Further anal. allowed us to provide some mol. insight into the diffusion mechanism in play. The QENS measurements report only a slight decrease of the self-diffusivity of CH4 in the presence of CO2 when the CO2 loading increases. Mol. dynamics simulations successfully capture this exptl. trend and suggest a plausible microscopic diffusion mechanism in the case of this binary mixt.

      Jobic, H.; Methivier, A.; Ehlers, G.; Farago, B.; Haeussler, W. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 364
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      92
      Accelerated diffusion of long-chain alkanes between nanosized cavities
      Jobic, Herve; Methivier, Alain; Ehlers, Georg; Farago, Bela; Haeussler, Wolfgang
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (3), 364-366CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      An anomalous transport effect was found by neutron spin echo measurements on n-alkanes diffusing in a small-pore zeolite: the diffusivity decreases from C1 to C8, but rises for C10 and has a max. at C12, then decreases again. This confirms the existence of the "window effect" proposed thirty years ago by Gorring (1973). It is shown schematically how one end of a C12 chain extends through a zeolite window, lowering the barrier to diffusion.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXntVehsA%253D%253D&md5=e0d773a9b695f205045ee20b62ca862b
    93. 93
      Chen, Y.-D.; Yang, R. T. Carbon 1998, 36, 1525
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      Surface and mesoporous diffusion with multilayer adsorption
      Chen, YuDong; Yang, Ralph T.
      Carbon (1998), 36 (10), 1525-1537CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      The theory by the authors on surface diffusion where multilayer adsorption occurs is reviewed (57 refs.) and discussed further. The theory is derived from a kinetic-theory approach for homogeneous surfaces, but is readily extendible to heterogeneous surfaces. The assumptions made in the BET theory are used. The theory is capable of predicting the increase and the subsequent decrease in surface diffusivity with surface concn. The required information for the theory is the equil. adsorption isotherm. From the theory, one can understand the fact that when the surface concn. approaches zero, the transport surface diffusivity becomes equal to the cor. surface diffusivity or self-diffusivity, which can be estd. readily from existing theories. On the other hand, when the surface concn. approaches infinity, i.e., when surface condensation occurs, the surface transport diffusivity approaches zero. A fair agreement is obtained between the data available in the literature and the theor. predictions. Finally, the concn. dependence of surface and mesoporous diffusivities is classified into five types. The multilayer surface diffusion theory is used to predict all five types of concn. dependence.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXmtlygsrw%253D&md5=f31144364b77348ed6122bdbb214434a

      Heink, W.; Karger, J.; Pfeifer, H.; Salverda, P.; Datema, K. P.; Nowak, A. J. Chem. Soc., Faraday Trans. 1992, 88, 515
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      94
      Self-diffusion measurements of n-alkanes in zeolite NaCaA by pulsed-field gradient nuclear magnetic resonance
      Heink, Wilfried; Kaerger, Joerg; Pfeifer, Harry; Salverda, Paul; Datema, Klaas P.; Nowak, Andreas
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions (1992), 88 (3), 515-19CODEN: JCFTEV; ISSN:0956-5000.
      Pulsed-field gradient (PFG) NMR is applied to the study of self-diffusion of the n-alkanes from methane to n-heptane, adsorbed in zeolite NaCaA. Using magnetic field gradients up to 10 T m-1 at -100 to 35£°, diffusivities between 10-13 and 10-8 m2 s-1 can be covered. For methane and ethane in NaCaA the diffusivity is found to increase by up to two orders of magnitude with increasing concn. In contrast to the case for zeolites NaX and HZSM-5, there is a dramatic jump in the chain-length dependence of the diffusivities between ethane and propane, corresponding to the fact that the crit. mol. diam. of propane and the longer n-alkanes is close to the diam. of the free apertures between adjacent supercages. With further increasing chain length there is a monotonic decrease in the diffusivities. The values obtained are in satisfactory agreement with the results of uptake measurements and neutron scattering expts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Ruthven, D. M.; Loughlin, K. F. J. Chem. Soc., Faraday Trans. I 1972, 68, 696
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      95
      Sorption of light paraffins in tupe-A zeolites. Analysis and interpretation of equilibrium isotherms
      Ruthven, D. M.; Loughlin, K. F.
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 1: Physical Chemistry in Condensed Phases (1972), 68 (4), 696-708CODEN: JCFTAR; ISSN:0300-9599.
      Equil. data for the sorption of CH4, C2H6, C3H8, and C4H10 in 5A zeolite, and C2H6 in 4A zeolite were interpreted by a simple idealized isotherm. Henry's law consts. and isosteric heats of sorption, calcd. from the model, agreed with exptl. values and values calcd. theoretically for CH4. The obsd. increase in isosteric heat of sorption with sorbate concn. arises from the effect of sorbate-sorbate repulsion (finite sorbate mol. size), and the effect of sorbate-sorbate attraction is minor. Entropies of sorption were compared with the values for ideal Langmuir adsorption and the limits of the Langmuir plot as a method of detg. Henry's law consts. and satn. consts. from exptl. equil. data are discussed.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE38XhtFyisbk%253D&md5=d0394073a4873876abc2c83efba5949d
    96. 96
      Fernandez, M.; Woo, T. K.; Wilmer, C. E.; Snurr, R. Q. J. Phys. Chem. C 2013, 117, 7681
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      96
      Large-Scale Quantitative Structure-Property Relationship (QSPR) Analysis of Methane Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Fernandez, Michael; Woo, Tom K.; Wilmer, Christopher E.; Snurr, Randall Q.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2013), 117 (15), 7681-7689CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) present a combinatorial design challenge. The structural building blocks of MOFs can be combined to synthesize a nearly infinite no. of materials. This suggests that computational tools, rather than exptl. trial and error, can be used for high-throughput screening. Here, in the context of methane storage, the first large-scale, quant. structure-property relationship (QSPR) anal. of MOFs is reported. The effect is investigated of geometrical features, such as pore size and void fraction, on the simulated methane storage capacities of ∼130 000 hypothetical MOFs at 1, 35, and 100 bar at 298 K. From these data models are developed that can predict methane storage with high accuracy, based only on knowledge of the geometric features. Several models were developed: multilinear regression (MLR) models, decision trees (DTs), and nonlinear support vector machines (SVMs). In each case, 10 000 MOF structures were used to "train" the QSPR regression models, and the accuracy of the predictions was evaluated on a test set of ∼120 000 MOFs. The nonlinear SVM models can predict the methane storage capacity of MOFs in the test set with R2 values of 0.82 and 0.93 at 35 and 100 bar, resp. Decision tree models produced rules for optimal design: for methane storage at 35 bar, MOFs should have densities greater than 0.43 g/cm3 and void fractions greater than 0.52; for methane storage at 100 bar, MOFs should have densities greater than 0.33 g/cm3 and void fractions greater than 0.62. Using two-dimensional response-surface analyses of the SVM models, new hypotheses is developed about combinations of material properties, yet unexplored, that might lead to very high methane storage capacities and warrant further investigation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXktlyltLo%253D&md5=e954a6ca876c9fca24b8649ba4fa7e12
    97. 97
      Chagger, H. K.; Ndaji, F. E.; Sykes, M. L.; Thomas, K. M. Carbon 1995, 33, 1405
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      97
      Kinetics of adsorption and diffusional characteristics of carbon molecular sieves
      Chagger, Harnit K.; Ndaji, Francis E.; Sykes, Martin L.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Carbon (1995), 33 (10), 1405-11CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier)
      Com. available carbon mol. sieve (CMS) materials, from a variety of sources, and mol. sieving carbons produced from the carbonization of coal have been studied. These materials have been assessed in terms of their kinetics of adsorption of oxygen and nitrogen. The diffusion kinetics of gases into the carbons have been analyzed using Fickian and phenomenol. models. The Arrhenius activating energies and pre-exponential factors for gas adsorption in the two types of material have been compared. The adsorption kinetic results are discussed in relation to structural models for carbon mol. sieves where the kinetic selectivity for gases has been introduced by carbon deposition in the case of com. CMS and by the variation of carbonization conditions in the case of the coal-based carbons produced in the lab.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXptlSltbg%253D&md5=bf368a756ee79cccddc713c7c2627e36

      Chmelik, C.; Bux, H.; Caro, J.; Heinke, L.; Hibbe, F.; Titze, T.; Kaerger, J. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2010, 104, 085902
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      98
      Mass Transfer in a Nanoscale Material Enhanced by an Opposing Flux
      Chmelik, Christian; Bux, Helge; Caro, Juergen; Heinke, Lars; Hibbe, Florian; Titze, Tobias; Kaerger, Joerg
      Physical Review Letters (2010), 104 (8), 085902/1-085902/4CODEN: PRLTAO; ISSN:0031-9007. (American Physical Society)
      Diffusion is known to be quantified by measuring the rate of mol. fluxes in the direction of falling concn. In contrast with intuition, considering methanol diffusion in a novel type of nanoporous material (MOF ZIF-8), this rate has now been found to be enhanced rather than slowed down by an opposing flux of labeled mols. In terms of the key quantities of random particle movement, this result means that the self-diffusivity exceeds the transport diffusivity. It is rationalized by considering the strong intermol. interaction and the dominating role of intercage hopping in mass transfer in the systems under study.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXisF2ht70%253D&md5=37da9ab36624b712f1846006dd419d8b

      Surface diffusion
      Kapoor, A.; Yang, R. T.; Wong, C.
      Catalysis Reviews - Science and Engineering (1989), 31 (1-2), 129-214CODEN: CRSEC9; ISSN:0161-4940.
      A review with 241 refs on surface diffusion of adsorbed and chemisorbed species.

      Rosenbach, N.; Jobic, H.; Ghoufi, A.; Salles, F.; Maurin, G.; Bourrelly, S.; Llewellyn, P. L.; Devic, T.; Serre, C.; Ferey, G. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 47, 6611
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      101
      Quasi-elastic neutron scattering and molecular dynamics study of methane diffusion in metal organic frameworks MIL-47(V) and MIL-53(Cr)
      Rosenbach, Nilton, Jr.; Jobic, Herve; Ghoufi, Aziz; Salles, Fabrice; Maurin, Guillaume; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Devic, Thomas; Serre, Christian; Ferey, Gerard
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (35), 6611-6615CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Diffusion of methane in the metal-org. frameworks MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-47(V) was elucidated by quasielastic neutron scattering and mol. dynamics simulation. The self-diffusivity of methane at low loading is very large, more than one order of magnitude higher than in zeolites.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVKhtr7N&md5=b19dbae8f0ce35dcfe665844c2d66a28
    102. 102
      Stallmach, F.; Groger, S.; Kunzel, V.; Karger, J.; Yaghi, O. M.; Hesse, M.; Muller, U. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45, 2123
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      102
      NMR studies on the diffusion of hydrocarbons on the metal-organic framework material MOF-5
      Stallmach, Frank; Groeger, Stefan; Kuenzel, Volker; Kaerger, Joerg; Yaghi, O. M.; Hesse, Michael; Mueller, Ulrich
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (13), 2123-2126CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      High intracryst. mobilities and fast exchange between the crystal and the surrounding gas phase were found in NMR studies on the diffusion of methane, ethane, n-hexane, and benzene in large crystals of the metal-org. framework MOF-5. The results support future use of metal-org. framework materials as tailorable sorbents for fast gas processing and gas-storage materials in industry.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xjt1OgsLg%253D&md5=17b936a4200371b62518ffd39a0ae3d9
    103. 103
      Hibbe, F.; Chmelik, C.; Heinke, L.; Pramanik, S.; Li, J.; Ruthven, D. M.; Tzoulaki, D.; Karger, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 2804
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      103
      The nature of surface barriers on nanoporous solids explored by microimaging of transient guest distributions
      Hibbe, Florian; Chmelik, Christian; Heinke, Lars; Pramanik, Sanhita; Li, Jing; Ruthven, Douglas M.; Tzoulaki, Despina; Karger, Jorg
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (9), 2804-2807CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Nanoporous solids are attractive materials for energetically efficient and environmentally friendly catalytic and adsorption sepn. processes. Although the performance of such materials is largely dependent on their mol. transport properties, the fundamental understanding of these phenomena is far from complete. This is particularly true for the mechanisms that control the penetration rate through the outer surface of these materials (commonly referred to as surface barriers). Recent detailed sorption rate measurements with Zn(tbip) crystals have greatly enhanced the basic understanding of such processes. Surface resistance in this material was shown to arise from the complete blockage of most of the pore entrances on the outer surface, while the transport resistance of the remaining open pores is negligibly small. More generally, the revealed correlation between intracryst. diffusion and surface permeation provides a new view of the nature of transport resistances in nanoporous materials acting in addn. to the diffusion resistance of the regular pore network, leading to a rational explanation of the discrepancy which is often obsd. between microscopic and macroscopic diffusion measurements.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhvFeisbY%253D&md5=a7c867f7b62e8a69d2aeac66a7fb7aab
    104. 104
      Zheng, B. S.; Bai, J. F.; Duan, J. G.; Wojtas, L.; Zaworotko, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 748
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      104
      Enhanced CO2 binding affinity of a high-uptake rht-type metal-organic framework decorated with acylamide groups
      Zheng, Baishu; Bai, Junfeng; Duan, Jingui; Wojtas, Lukasz; Zaworotko, Michael J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (4), 748-751CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      An rht-type metal-org. framework (MOF) prepd. from M2(carboxylate)4 (M = Cu, Co) paddlewheel clusters and a flexible C3-sym. hexacarboxylate ligand with acylamide groups exhibits larger CO2 uptake, an enhanced heat of adsorption, and higher selectivity toward CO2/N2 in comparison with what was previously obsd. for an analogous MOF with alkyne groups.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsF2ku77O&md5=d6d344c487e474f8969de5720df246c8
    105. 105
      Liang, Z. J.; Marshall, M.; Chaffee, A. L. Energy Fuels 2009, 23, 2785
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      105
      CO2 Adsorption-Based Separation by Metal Organic Framework (Cu-BTC) versus Zeolite (13X)
      Liang, Zhijian; Marshall, Marc; Chaffee, Alan L.
      Energy & Fuels (2009), 23 (5), 2785-2789CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
      The potential for the metal org. framework (MOF) Cu-BTC (copper 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate trihydrate) to selectively adsorb and sep. CO2 is considered. Isotherms for CO2, CH4, and N2 were measured at 0-15 bar and 25-105°. The isotherms suggest a much higher working capacity (×4) for CO2 adsorption on Cu-BTC relative to the benchmark zeolite 13X over the same pressure range. Higher CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivities in the higher pressure range (1-15 bar) and with lower heats of adsorption were also demonstrated. Cu-BTC was stable in O2 at 25°, but its crystallinity was reduced in humid environments. The CO2 adsorption capacity was progressively reduced upon cyclic exposure to water vapor at low relative humidity (<30%), but leveled out at 75% of its original value after several water adsorption/desorption cycles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXksFags7s%253D&md5=b2cee74813854154a3f6a8d2b5ec2d60
    106. 106
      Wang, X. S.; Ma, S. Q.; Rauch, K.; Simmons, J. M.; Yuan, D.; Wang, X. P.; Yildirim, T.; Cole, W. C.; Lopez, J. J.; Meijere, A. D.; Zhou, H. C. Chem. Mater. 2008, 20, 3145
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      106
      Metal-organic frameworks based on double-bond-coupled di-isophthalate linkers with high hydrogen and methane uptakes
      Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Rauch, Karsten; Simmons, Jason M.; Yuan, Daqiang; Wang, Xiaoping; Yildirim, Taner; Cole, William C.; Lopez, Joseph J.; de Meijere, Armin; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Chemistry of Materials (2008), 20 (9), 3145-3152CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2 with azoxybenzene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4aobtc) or trans-stilbene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4sbtc) give rise to two isostructural microporous metal-org. frameworks, Cu2(abtc)(H2O)2·3DMA (PCN-10, abtc = azobenzene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylate) and Cu2(sbtc)(H2O)2·3DMA (PCN-11, sbtc = trans-stilbene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylate), resp. Both PCN-10 and PCN-11 possess significant enduring porosity with Langmuir surface areas of 1779 and 2442 m2/g (corresponding to BET surface areas of 1407 or 1931 m2/g, resp.) and contain nanoscopic cages and coordinatively unsatd. metal centers. At 77 K, 760 torr, the excess gravimetric (volumetric) H uptake of PCN-10 is 2.34% (18.0 g/L) and that of PCN-11 can reach 2.55% (19.1 g/L). Gas-adsorption studies also suggest that MOFs contg. C=C double bonds are more favorable than those with N=N double bond in retaining enduring porosity after thermal activation, although N=N has slightly higher H2 affinity. The excess gravimetric (volumetric) adsorption at 77 K sats. around 20 atm and reaches values of 4.33% (33.2 g/L) and 5.05% (37.8 g/L) for PCN-10 and PCN-11, resp. In addn. to its appreciable H uptake, PCN-11 has an excess methane uptake of 171 cm3(STP)/cm3 at 298 K and 35 bar, approaching the DOE target of 180 v(STP)/v for methane storage at ambient temp. Thus, PCN-11 represents one of the few materials that is applicable to both H and methane storage applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXks1Wntrg%253D&md5=6eed170518b1b0e0a55210482cc0ef50
    107. 107
      Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2008, 112, 108
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      107
      High pressure methane adsorption in the metal-organic frameworks Cu3(btc)2, Zn2(bdc)2dabco, and Cr3F(H2O)2O(bdc)3
      Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2008), 112 (1-3), 108-115CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier)
      Three porous coordination polymers Cu3(btc)2 (HKUST-1) (btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) (1), Zn2(bdc)2dabco (2) (bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), and Cr3F(H2O)2O(bdc)3 (MIL-101) (3) were evaluated as methane storage materials. The compds. were synthesized using solvothermal method and identified as pure phases using powder x-ray diffraction. Nitrogen physisorption at 77 K revealed a high specific micropore vol. ranging from 0.75 to 1.303 cm3 g-1. Methane adsorption isotherms were measured using gravimetric method at 303 K up to 200 bar. A volumetric miniature tank system was used to measure the effective volumetric storage capacity taking the packing d. into account. Among the three materials, Cu3(btc)2 shows the highest excess adsorption at 303 K (15.7%) and effective volumetric storage capacity of 228 m3 m-3 (150 bar), whereas for Zn2(bdc)2dabco and MIL-101 the max. excess adsorption is lower (14.3 and 14.2%, resp.). For MIL-101, the max. in the excess adsorption is obsd. at higher pressure (125 bar) as compared to Cu3(btc)2 and Zn2(bdc)2dabco (75 bar).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXmtVKhuro%253D&md5=80f083c98277be7a0bcfa65010830965

      Peng, Y.; Srinivas, G.; Wilmer, C. E.; Eryazici, I.; Snurr, R. Q.; Hupp, J. T.; Yildirim, T.; Farha, O. K. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49, 2992
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      108
      Simultaneously high gravimetric and volumetric methane uptake characteristics of the metal-organic framework NU-111
      Peng, Yang; Srinivas, Gadipelli; Wilmer, Christopher E.; Eryazici, Ibrahim; Snurr, Randall Q.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Yildirim, Taner; Farha, Omar K.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (29), 2992-2994CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The MOF NU-111 exhibits equally high volumetric and gravimetric methane uptake values, both within ≈75% of the DOE targets at 300 K. Upon reducing the temp. to 270 K, the uptake increases to 0.5 g g-1 and 284 cc(STP) per cc at 65 bar. Adsorption of CO2 and H2 is also reported. Simulated isotherms are in excellent agreement with those obtained from expts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjvFWgs7s%253D&md5=3e8859eb261343b0b7bd54ee295c9859

      Duan, X.; Yu, J.; Cai, J.; He, Y.; Wu, C.; Zhou, W.; Yildirim, T.; Zhang, Z.; Xiang, S.; O’Keeffe, M.; Chen, B.; Qian, G. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49, 2043
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      109
      A microporous metal-organic framework of a rare sty topology for high CH4 storage at room temperature
      Duan, Xing; Yu, Jiancan; Cai, Jianfeng; He, Yabing; Wu, Chuande; Zhou, Wei; Yildirim, Taner; Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin; Qian, Guodong
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (20), 2043-2045CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A rare sty type microporous metal-org. framework, [Cu2(FDDI)(H2O)2](DMF)7(H2O) (ZJU-25; H4FDDI = tetra-Me 5,5'-(9H-fluorene-2,7-diyl)diisophthalate acid), was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. With open metal sites and suitable pore space for their interactions with methane mols., activated ZJU-25a exhibits abs. methane storage of 180 cm3(STP) cm-3 at room temp. and 35 bar, enabling it to be one of the very few porous MOFs whose methane storage capacities have met and/or approached the DOE target of 180 cm3(STP) cm-3 for material-based methane storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      1. 1
        Makal, T. A.; Li, J. R.; Lu, W. G.; Zhou, H. C. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41, 7761
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Methane storage in advanced porous materials
        Makal, Trevor A.; Li, Jian-Rong; Lu, Weigang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (23), 7761-7779CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The need for alternative fuels is greater now than ever before. With considerable sources available and low pollution factor, methane is a natural choice as petroleum replacement in cars and other mobile applications. However, efficient storage methods are still lacking to implement the application of methane in the automotive industry. Advanced porous materials, metal-org. frameworks and porous org. polymers, have received considerable attention in sorptive storage applications owing to their exceptionally high surface areas and chem.-tunable structures. In this crit. review we provide an overview of the current status of the application of these two types of advanced porous materials in the storage of methane. Examples of materials exhibiting high methane storage capacities are analyzed and methods for increasing the applicability of these advanced porous materials in methane storage technologies described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhs1ahtb3N&md5=453174cd0cb3602aaab6b0355c960996
      2. 2
        Sculley, J.; Yuan, D. Q.; Zhou, H. C. Energy Environ. Sci. 2011, 4, 2721
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        The current status of hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks-updated
        Sculley, Julian; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Energy & Environmental Science (2011), 4 (8), 2721-2735CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Hydrogen storage in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), or porous coordination polymers, has been extensively investigated in the last two years and this review is to serve as an up to date account of the recent progress. The effects of MOF sample prepn. and activation, functionalization (including post-synthetic), catenation, unsatd. metal sites, metal doping and spillover have been discussed using recent examples. In addn. to a condensed ref. table of all recently reported MOFs for hydrogen storage, future directions are discussed based on promising new materials and reported computational analyses.

        He, Y. B.; Zhou, W.; Krishna, R.; Chen, B. L. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 11813

        3
        Microporous metal-organic frameworks for storage and separation of small hydrocarbons
        He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (97), 11813-11831CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Hydrocarbons are very important energy resources and raw materials for some industrially important products and fine chems. There is a need for the discovery of better materials that offer enhanced capacities for safe storage of hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the development of improved sepn. technologies will lead to significant redn. in energy requirements and costs. In this feature article, we provide an overview of the current status of the emerging microporous metal-org. frameworks for the storage and sepn. of small hydrocarbons.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslCnsLjO&md5=c27c3682fac56f8d80b2f7ff420d3b7e
      4. 4
        Sircar, S. Adsorpt. Sci. Technol. 2001, 19, 347
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Applications of gas separation by adsorption for the future
        Sircar, S.
        Adsorption Science & Technology (2001), 19 (5), 347-366CODEN: ASTEEZ; ISSN:0263-6174. (Multi-Science Publishing Co. Ltd.)
        The sepn. and purifn. of gas mixts. by adsorption has found numerous industrial applications during the past 30 yr. The very active research and development in this field is driven by (a) the highly flexible nature of cyclic adsorptive process designs, (b) the availability of many adsorbents for the sepn., and (c) the multiple choice of adsorbent-process design combinations for achieving the desired sepn. goals. The trend is to improve the product quality and sepn. efficiency, as well as to increase the scale of application of this technol. The design of processes by using faster cycles and the use of innovative adsorber configurations are two new directions. Hybrid gas sepn. and prodn. concepts such as adsorbent membranes and simultaneous sorption-reaction schemes are emerging areas that may open new frontiers of application for this technol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XptV2rtg%253D%253D&md5=b54be4feda6fab8e094e77284a2e63aa
      5. 5
        Sircar, S.; Golden, T. C.; Rao, M. B. Carbon 1996, 34, 1
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Activated-carbon for gas separation and storage
        Sircar, S.; Golden, T. C.; Rao, M. B.
        Carbon (1996), 34 (1), 1-12CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier)
        Activated carbons offer a large spectrum of pore structures and surface chem. for adsorption of gases, which are being used to design practical pressure swing and thermal swing adsorption processes for sepn. and purifn. of gas mixts. The activated carbons are often preferred over the zeolitic adsorbents in a gas sepn. process because of their relatively moderate strengths of adsorption for gases, which facilitate the desorption process. Three com. applications of activated carbons, (a) trace impurity removal from a contaminated gas, (b) prodn. of hydrogen from a steam-methane reformer off gas, and (c) prodn. of nitrogen from air, are considered. Four novel applications of activated carbons for gas sepn. and purifn. are also described. They include, (a) sepn. of hydrogen-hydrocarbon mixts. by selective surface flow of larger hydrocarbon mols. through a nanoporous carbon membrane produced by carbonization of a polymer matrix, (b) gas drying by pressure swing adsorption using a water selective microporous carbon adsorbent produced by surface oxidn. of a hydrophobic carbon, (c) removal by selective adsorption and in-situ oxidn. of trace volatile org. compds. from air by using a carbon adsorbent-catalyst composite, and (d) storage of compressed natural gas on high surface area carbons.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Metal-Organic Frameworks for Separations
        Li, Jian-Rong; Sculley, Julian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 869-932CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. This article reviews the metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous solid materials. Their performances for applications in sepns. and purifications is attracting intense interest of researchers working in the fields of chem., chem. engineering, materials science, and others. Despite being in its infancy, the research progress in this subject has already shown that MOFs are promising for sepn. applications.

      7. 7
        Bell, J. G.; Angus, K.; Todd, C.; Thomas, K. M. Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2013, 52, 1335
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Functional Hollow Fiber Adsorbent Materials with a Self-Regulating Composite Outer Layer for Gas Purification with Energy Efficient Electrothermal Regeneration
        Bell, Jon G.; Angus, Katy; Todd, Christopher; Thomas, K. Mark
        Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2013), 52 (3), 1335-1351CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
        Hollow fiber adsorbents have potential to overcome high pressure drop, adsorbent bed settling, and channeling problems in fixed bed adsorption systems. A coaxial spinning method was used for the synthesis of hollow fibers with an outer layer of elec. conducting polyvinylidene fluoride/carbon black composite with a pos. temp. coeff. of resistivity and an inner layer of zeolite 13X/polyethersulfone adsorbent. The outer layer was optimized for self-limiting/regulating a.c. (AC) electrothermal regeneration. A fiber cartridge was constructed for studying the dynamic breakthrough and adsorbent regeneration characteristics. The breakthrough results for water vapor adsorption were analyzed by Wheeler-Jonas, Linear Driving Force (LDF) and Richards sigmoidal models. The isosteric enthalpy and kinetics for adsorption were detd. for static vapor adsorption. The LDF adsorption kinetics obsd. at low surface coverage change to a stretched exponential kinetic model with increasing surface coverage. Intraparticle diffusion in the zeolite cryst. porous structure was rate-detg. for water vapor breakthrough characteristics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVCjurnJ&md5=d6c36f1feff74055ba8d3b30cfc27693
      8. 8
        Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. B 2001, 105, 10619
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Adsorption Kinetics and Size Exclusion Properties of Probe Molecules for the Selective Porosity in a Carbon Molecular Sieve Used for Air Separation
        Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2001), 105 (43), 10619-10629CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1089-5647. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption characteristics of planar (ethylene, benzene, and pyridine) and tetrahedral (methane, chloromethane, dichloromethane, chloroform, and carbon tetrachloride) mols. on a carbon mol. sieve used for air sepn. (CMS A) were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure, to study the selective porosity. The size-exclusion characteristics of planar and tetrahedral mols. indicate that the selective porosity behaves as though it has spherical-shaped structural characteristics and, therefore, two min. dimensions need to be considered in relation to size exclusion. The partial exclusion of the probe mol. adsorptives from the microporous structure for sizes >360 pm allowed the selective and nonselective microporosity and the meso/macroporosity to be quantified. Adsorption kinetics obey a linear-driving-force mass transfer, combined barrier resistance/diffusion, or Fickian kinetic models depending on the adsorptive and exptl. conditions. Comparison of the results with previous studies of the adsorption of linear and spherical mols. on CMS A show that a decrease in the adsorption rate const. of ∼4 orders of magnitude was obsd. for an increase in mol. size over the range ∼290-420 pm. The activation energies and preexponential factors for the adsorption kinetics and the isosteric heats of adsorption are discussed in terms of the structural characteristics of the adsorptives and the adsorption mechanism.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        9
        Microporous organic polymers for methane storage
        Wood, Colin D.; Tan, Bien; Trewin, Abbie; Su, Fabing; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.; Bradshaw, Darren; Sun, Yan; Zhou, Li; Cooper, Andrew I.
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2008), 20 (10), 1916-1921CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Methane storage is important for the development of alternative energy carriers. The synthesis and methane storage properties of microporous hypercrosslinked org. polymers are reported. The figure shows a simulation of methane sorption in microporous hypercrosslinked poly(p-dichloroxylene); up to 5.2 mmol g-1 CH4 at 20 bar/298 K; isosteric heat of sorption ∼21 kJ mol-1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXns1ymt7s%253D&md5=5c3714b4fb0b6b089eec55f18dc083f2
      10. 10
        Guo, Z. Y.; Wu, H.; Srinivas, G.; Zhou, Y. M.; Xiang, S. C.; Chen, Z. X.; Yang, Y. T.; Zhou, W.; O’Keeffe, M.; Chen, B. L. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2011, 50, 3178
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        A Metal-Organic Framework with Optimized Open Metal Sites and Pore Spaces for High Methane Storage at Room Temperature
        Guo, Zhiyong; Wu, Hui; Srinivas, Gadipelli; Zhou, Yaming; Xiang, Shengchang; Chen, Zhenxia; Yang, Yongtai; Zhou, Wei; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2011), 50 (14), 3178-3181, S3178/1-S3178/10CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A 3D porous metal-org. framework (MOF) complex (UTSA-20) based on a novel trinodal (3,3,4) net of zyg topol. by the self-assembly of the nonlinear hexacarboxylate (BHB) with the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 cluster was prepd. Although its porosity and surface area are moderate and much lower than those of most highly porous MOFs, the open copper sites and optimal pore spaces within UTSA-20 have enabled the pore spaces to be fully utilized for methane storage, featuring UTSA-20 as the material with the highest methane storage d. (0.222 g·cm-3), and just the third porous MOF whose abs. volumetric methane storage has surpassed the DOE methane storage target of 180 cm3cm-3 at room temp. and 35 bar. By the immobilization of a high d. of open metal sites and the deliberate control of the pore space for their efficient methane storage, these new porous MOFs are envisioned to be promising media for methane and natural gas storage, particularly for mobile applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjsFyrurc%253D&md5=d8075817197078a256d749baf8856ce6
      11. 11
        Celzard, A.; Fierro, V. Energy Fuels 2005, 19, 573
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Preparing a Suitable Material Designed for Methane Storage: A Comprehensive Report
        Celzard, A.; Fierro, V.
        Energy & Fuels (2005), 19 (2), 573-583CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The prepn. of a suitable material designed for methane storage is addressed in the present paper. The main features of methane as an energy source are first recalled, and adsorption is recognized as one of the most efficient ways of storing it. The ideal adsorbent is described next, and it is argued that the best candidates are among microporous carbonaceous materials. Prepn. of the most relevant carbon requires appropriate choice of both the precursor and its mode of activation. A discussion leads to the conclusion that anthracites chem. activated with alk. hydroxides are esp. adapted for the intended application, because the highest intrinsic molar capacities ever found so far in the open literature are obtained. However, because of their low d., only low-vol. storage capacities are attained with such materials. It is then shown that simple processing allows a significant densification, and, therefore, the formerly accepted target for a viable application of methane as an alternative fuel-150 V/V delivered at 25 °C-is finally met and even exceeded. Thus, the present work is a comprehensive report explaining how a recent problem was solved through a systematical approach.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtVSnt7o%253D&md5=c78d19bfd7eda10970d087353003a2d5
      12. 12
        Duren, T.; Sarkisov, L.; Yaghi, O. M.; Snurr, R. Q. Langmuir 2004, 20, 2683
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Design of new materials for methane storage
        Duren Tina; Sarkisov Lev; Yaghi Omar M; Snurr Randall Q
        Langmuir : the ACS journal of surfaces and colloids (2004), 20 (7), 2683-9 ISSN:0743-7463.
        One of the strategic goals of the modern automobile manufacturing industry is to replace gasoline and diesel with alternative fuels such as natural gas. In this report, we elucidate the desired characteristics of an optimal adsorbent for gas storage. The U.S. Department of Energy has outlined several requirements that adsorbents must fulfill for natural gas to become economically viable, with a key criterion being the amount adsorbed at 35 bar. We explore the adsorption characteristics of novel metal-organic materials (IRMOFs and molecular squares) and contrast them with the characteristics of two zeolites, MCM-41, and different carbon nanotubes. Using molecular simulations, we uncover the complex interplay of the factors influencing methane adsorption, especially the surface area, the capacity or free volume, the strength of the energetic interaction, and the pore size distribution. We also explain the extraordinary adsorption properties of IRMOF materials and propose new, not yet synthesized IRMOF structures with adsorption characteristics that are predicted to exceed the best experimental results to date by up to 36%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2M3gtFWquw%253D%253D&md5=0f10aca88c4253004548b2ba1dae20b3

      14. 14
        Yaghi, O. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Ockwig, N. W.; Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J. Nature 2003, 423, 705
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea

        Ferey, G.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Serre, C.; Millange, F.; Dutour, J.; Surble, S.; Margiolaki, I. Science 2005, 309, 2040
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A Chromium Terephthalate-Based Solid with Unusually Large Pore Volumes and Surface Area
        Ferey, G.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Serre, C.; Millange, F.; Dutour, J.; Surble, S.; Margiolaki, I.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2005), 309 (5743), 2040-2042CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        We combined targeted chem. and computational design to create a crystal structure for porous chromium terephthalate, MIL-101, with very large pore sizes and surface area. Its zeotype cubic structure has a giant cell vol. (∼702,000 cubic angstroms), a hierarchy of extra-large pore sizes (∼30 to 34 angstroms), and a Langmuir surface area for N2 of ∼5900 ± 300 square meters per g. Beside the usual properties of porous compds., this solid has potential as a nanomold for monodisperse nanomaterials, as illustrated here by the incorporation of Keggin polyanions within the cages.

        Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95

        Xiao, B.; Wheatley, P. S.; Zhao, X.; Fletcher, A. J.; Fox, S.; Rossi, A. G.; Megson, I. L.; Bordiga, S.; Regli, L.; Thomas, K. M.; Morris, R. E. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 1203
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        High-Capacity Hydrogen and Nitric Oxide Adsorption and Storage in a Metal-Organic Framework
        Xiao, Bo; Wheatley, Paul S.; Zhao, Xuebo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Fox, Sarah; Rossi, Adriano G.; Megson, Ian L.; Bordiga, S.; Regli, L.; Thomas, K. Mark; Morris, Russell E.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (5), 1203-1209CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Gas adsorption expts. were carried out on a Cu benzene tricarboxylate metal-org. framework material, HKUST-1. Hydrogen adsorption at 1 and 10 bar (both 77 K) gives an adsorption capacity of 11.16 mmol H2 per g of HKUST-1 (22.7 mg g-1, 2.27%) at 1 bar and 18 mmol per g (36.28 mg g-1, 3.6%) at 10 bar. Adsorption of D2 at 1 bar (77 K) is between 1.09 (at 1 bar) and 1.20(at <100 mbar) times the H2 values depending on the pressure, agreeing with the theor. expectations. Gravimetric adsorption measurements of NO on HKUST-1 at 196 K (1 bar) gives a large adsorption capacity of ∼9 mmol g-1, which is significantly greater than any other adsorption capacity reported on a porous solid. At 298 K the adsorption capacity at 1 bar is just over 3 mmol g-1. Infra red expts. show that the NO binds to the empty Cu metal sites in HKUST-1. Chemiluminescence and platelet aggregometry expts. indicate that the amt. of NO recovered on exposure of the resulting complex to H2O is enough to be biol. active, completely inhibiting platelet aggregation in platelet rich plasma.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhvVCjug%253D%253D&md5=ece5be8da39d229b9db7f7dc838de82a

        Xiang, S. C.; Zhang, Z. J.; Zhao, C. G.; Hong, K. L.; Zhao, X. B.; Ding, D. R.; Xie, M. H.; Wu, C. D.; Das, M. C.; Gill, R.; Thomas, K. M.; Chen, B. L. Nat. Commun. 2011, 2, 204
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
