        Rationally tuned micropores within enantiopure metal-organic frameworks for highly selective separation of acetylene and ethylene
        Xiang Sheng-Chang; Zhang Zhangjing; Zhao Cong-Gui; Hong Kunlun; Zhao Xuebo; Ding De-Rong; Xie Ming-Hua; Wu Chuan-De; Das Madhab C; Gill Rachel; Thomas K Mark; Chen Banglin
        Nature communications (2011), 2 (), 204 ISSN:.
        Separation of acetylene and ethylene is an important industrial process because both compounds are essential reagents for a range of chemical products and materials. Current separation approaches include the partial hydrogenation of acetylene into ethylene over a supported Pd catalyst, and the extraction of cracked olefins using an organic solvent; both routes are costly and energy consuming. Adsorption technologies may allow separation, but microporous materials exhibiting highly selective adsorption of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4) have not been realized to date. Here, we report the development of tunable microporous enantiopure mixed-metal-organic framework (M'MOF) materials for highly selective separation of C(2)H(2) and C(2)H(4). The high selectivities achieved suggest the potential application of microporous M'MOFs for practical adsorption-based separation of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4).

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M3htlSrtg%253D%253D&md5=1fb20400fe51c39c12dee76feb72858e

        Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; Li, H.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2001, 34, 319
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Modular Chemistry: Secondary Building Units as a Basis for the Design of Highly Porous and Robust Metal-Organic Carboxylate Frameworks
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; Li, Hailian; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (4), 319-330CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFymsL0%253D&md5=e3df2f7492090aee280676f044e3b7af

        Chen, B.; Zhao, X.; Putkham, A.; Hong, K.; Lobkovsky, E. B.; Hurtado, E. J.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 6411
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Surface Interactions and Quantum Kinetic Molecular Sieving for H2 and D2 Adsorption on a Mixed Metal-Organic Framework Material
        Chen, Banglin; Zhao, Xuebo; Putkham, Apipong; Hong, Kunlun; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Hurtado, Eric J.; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (20), 6411-6423CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A rational strategy was used to immobilize open metal sites in ultramicroporosity for stronger binding of multiple H2 mols. per unsatd. metal site for H2 storage applications. The synthesis and structure of a mixed Zn/Cu metal-org. framework material Zn3(BDC)3[Cu(Pyen)]·(DMF)5(H2O)5 (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid and PyenH2 = (5-methyl-4-hydroxopyridine-3-methylene)ethylenediaminecarbaldehyde) is reported. Desolvation provides a bimodal porous structure Zn3(BDC)3[Cu(Pyen)] (M'MOF 1) with narrow porosity (<0.56 nm) and an array of pores in the bc crystallog. plane where the adsorbate-adsorbent interactions are maximized by both the presence of open Cu centers and overlap of the potential energy fields from pore walls. The H2 and D2 adsorption isotherms for M'MOF 1 at 77.3 and 87.3 K were reversible with virtually no hysteresis. Methods for detn. of the isosteric enthalpies of H2 and D2 adsorption were compared. A virial model gave the best agreement (av. deviation <1 std. deviation) with the isotherm data. This was used in conjunction with the van't Hoff isochore giving isosteric enthalpies at zero surface coverage of 12.29 ± 0.53 and 12.44 ± 0.50 kJ mol-1 for H2 and D2 adsorption, resp. This is the highest value so far obsd. for H adsorption on a porous material. The enthalpy of adsorption, decreases with increasing amt. adsorbed to 9.5 kJ mol-1 at .ltorsim.≈1.9 mmol g-1 (2 H2 or D2 mols. per Cu corresponding to adsorption on both sides of planar Cu open centers) and is virtually unchanged in the range 1.9-3.6 mmol g-1. Virial anal. of isotherms at 87.3 K is also consistent with 2 H2 or D2 mols. being bound to each open Cu center. The adsorption kinetics follow a double exponential model, corresponding to diffusion along 2 types of pores, a slow component with high activation energy (13.35 ± 0.59 kJ mol-1) for the narrow pores and a faster component with low activation energy (8.56 ± 0.41 kJ mol-1). The D2 adsorption kinetic consts. for both components were significantly faster than the corresponding H2 kinetics for specific pressure increments and had slightly lower activation energies than the corresponding values for H2 adsorption. The kD2/kH2 ratio for the slow component was 1.62 ± 0.07, while the fast component was 1.38 ± 0.04 at 77.3 K, and the corresponding ratios were smaller at 87.3 K. These observations of kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving in porous materials are due to the larger zero-point energy for the lighter H2, resulting in slower adsorption kinetics compared with the heavier D2. A combination of open metal centers and confinement in ultramicroporosity leads to a high enthalpy for H2 adsorption over a wide range of surface coverage and quantum effects influence diffusion of H2 and D2 in pores in M'MOF 1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXltVyjsLo%253D&md5=cd9993fbfa093dfecfd6324ec8f7d042
      21. 21
        Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b

        Wu, H.; Simmons, J. M.; Liu, Y.; Brown, C. M.; Wang, X. S.; Ma, S.; Peterson, V. K.; Southon, P. D.; Kepert, C. J.; Zhou, H. C.; Yildirim, T.; Zhou, W. Chem.—Eur. J. 2010, 16, 5205
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Methane Uptake: Where and How is Methane Stored?
        Wu, Hui; Simmons, Jason M.; Liu, Yun; Brown, Craig M.; Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Peterson, Vanessa K.; Southon, Peter D.; Kepert, Cameron J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai; Yildirim, Taner; Zhou, Wei
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (17), 5205-5214, S5205/1-S5205/16CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a novel family of physisorptive materials that have exhibited great promise for methane storage. So far, a detailed understanding of their methane adsorption mechanism is still scarce. Herein, we report a comprehensive mechanistic study of methane storage in three milestone MOF compds. (HKUST-1, PCN-11, and PCN-14) the CH4 storage capacities of which are among the highest reported so far among all porous materials. The three MOFs consist of the same dicopper paddle-wheel secondary building units, but contain different org. linkers, leading to cagelike pores with various sizes and geometries. From neutron powder diffraction expts. and accurate data anal., assisted by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations and DFT calcns., we unambiguously revealed the exact locations of the stored methane mols. in these MOF materials. We found that methane uptake takes place primarily at two types of strong adsorption site: (1) the open Cu coordination sites, which exhibit enhanced Coulomb attraction toward methane, and (2) the van der Waals potential pocket sites, in which the total dispersive interactions are enhanced due to the mol. being in contact with multiple "surfaces.". Interestingly, the enhanced van der Waals sites are present exclusively in small cages and at the windows to these cages, whereas large cages with relatively flat pore surfaces bind very little methane. Our results suggest that further, rational development of new MOF compds. for methane storage applications should focus on enriching open metal sites, increasing the vol. percentage of accessible small cages and channels, and minimizing the fraction of large pores.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXltlWgtb0%253D&md5=8f6059d2e137ca23fb5eeb17d127be74

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Rational synthesis of stable channel-like cavities with methane gas adsorption properties: [{Cu2(pzdc)2(L)}n] (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; L =a pillar ligand)
        Kondo, Mitsuru; Okubo, Takashi; Asami, Akiko; Noro, Shin-Ichiro; Yoshitomi, Tomomichi; Kitagawa, Susumu; Ishii, Tomohiko; Matsuzaka, Hiroyuki; Seki, Kenji
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1999), 38 (1/2), 140-143CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Porous coordination networks were designed in prepd. copper complexes [{Cu2(pzdc)2(L)}n] (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; L = pillar ligand pyrazine, 4,4'-bipyridyl, N-4-pyridinyl-4-pyridinecarboxamide). The structure of [{Cu2(pzdc)2(pyz)}.2H2O]n (1) was detd. by x-ray crystallog. The complex consists of a pillared layer structure with a two-dimensional sheet of [Cu(pzdc)2]n and pillar pyrazine ligands that bridge each sheet. The channels are occupied by water mols. Thermal dehydration of 1 at 100-260° resulted in a stable phase which retained the porous network without decompn. (powder XRD study). Methane adsorption capabilities of the coordination networks were studied. Increased methane absorption activity for pillar ligands 4,4'-bipyridyl and N-4-pyridinyl-4-pyridinecarboxamide is consistent with the larger channel sizes of these complexes. The activity is comparable to that of zeolites and other reported stable porous coordination networks.

        An Isoreticular Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks with Dendritic Hexacarboxylate Ligands and Exceptionally High Gas-Uptake Capacity
        Yuan, Daqiang; Zhao, Dan; Sun, Daofeng; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (31), 5357-5361, S5357/1-S5357/12CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An isoreticular metal-org. framework series with the (3,24)-connected network topol. has been synthesized by using a series of dendritic hexacarboxylate ligands. The framework is stabilized by incorporating microwindows whose size is fixed by the formation of cuboctahedral supported by the isophthalate moieties throughout the framework. Adsorption studies using hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide reveal that they have close to record-high gas adsorption capacities.

        A Highly Porous Metal-Organic Framework with Open Nickel Sites
        Gedrich, Kristina; Senkovska, Irena; Klein, Nicole; Stoeck, Ulrich; Henschel, Antje; Lohe, Martin R.; Baburin, Igor A.; Mueller, Uwe; Kaskel, Stefan
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (45), 8489-8492, S8489/1-S8489/14CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new highly porous material, DUT-9, [Ni5O2(btb)2(L)4(H2O)4], was prepd. from solvothermal reaction of nickel nitrate with H3btb (benzene-1,3,5-tri-p-benzoic acid) and L (diethylformamide or dimethylformamide), and characterized by x-ray crystallog. DUT-9 contains open nickel sites, exhibits remarkable adsorption properties, large pores of up to 25 Å wide, a new network topol., and has high potential for gas storage, CO2 sepn., and catalytic applications.

        Metal-Organic Framework from an Anthracene Derivative Containing Nanoscopic Cages Exhibiting High Methane Uptake
        Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Simmons, Jason M.; Collier, Christopher D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (3), 1012-1016CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework, PCN-14, based on an anthracene deriv., 5,5'- (9,10-anthracene-diyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip), was synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. X-ray single crystal anal. revealed that PCN-14 consists of nanoscopic cages suitable for gas storage. N2-adsorption studies of PCN-14 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 2176 m2/g and a pore vol. of 0.87 cm3/g. Methane adsorption studies at 290 K and 35 bar show that PCN-14 exhibits an abs. methane-adsorption capacity of 230 vol./vol., 28% higher than the DOE target (180 vol./vol.) for methane storage.

        Wilmer, C. E.; Leaf, M.; Lee, C. Y.; Farha, O. K.; Hauser, B. G.; Hupp, J. T.; Snurr, R. Q. Nat. Chem. 2012, 4, 83
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Large-scale screening of hypothetical metal-organic frameworks
        Wilmer, Christopher E.; Leaf, Michael; Lee, Chang Yeon; Farha, Omar K.; Hauser, Brad G.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Snurr, Randall Q.
        Nature Chemistry (2012), 4 (2), 83-89CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials constructed from modular mol. building blocks, typically metal clusters and org. linkers. These can, in principle, be assembled to form an almost unlimited no. of MOFs, yet materials reported to date represent only a tiny fraction of the possible combinations. Here, the authors demonstrate a computational approach to generate all conceivable MOFs from a given chem. library of building blocks (based on the structures of known MOFs) and rapidly screen them to find the best candidates for a specific application. From a library of 102 building blocks the authors generated 137,953 hypothetical MOFs and for each calcd. the pore-size distribution, surface area and methane-storage capacity. The authors identified over 300 MOFs with a predicted methane-storage capacity better than that of any known material, and this approach also revealed structure-property relations. Methyl-functionalized MOFs were frequently top performers, so the authors selected one such promising MOF and exptl. confirmed its predicted capacity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVagtL3K&md5=3becbfed2fdacdb8b58146666da7c038
      29. 29
        Wu, H.; Zhou, W.; Yildirim, T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 4995
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        High-Capacity Methane Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks M2(dhtp): The Important Role of Open Metal Sites
        Wu, Hui; Zhou, Wei; Yildirim, Taner
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (13), 4995-5000CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. framework (MOF) compds. M2(dhtp) (open metal M = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, Zn; dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalate) possess exceptionally large densities of open metal sites. By adsorbing one CH4 mol. per open metal, these sites alone can generate very large methane storage capacities, 160-174 cm3(STP)/cm3, approaching the DOE target of 180 cm3(STP)/cm3 for material-based methane storage at room temp. The adsorption isotherm measurements at 298 K and 35 bar for the five M2(dhtp) compds. yield excess methane adsorption capacities ranging from 149 to 190 cm3(STP)/cm3 (derived using their crystal densities), indeed roughly equal to the predicted, maximal adsorption capacities of the open metals (within ±10%) in these MOFs. Among the five isostructural MOFs studied, Ni2(dhtp) exhibits the highest methane storage capacity, ∼200 cm3(STP)/cm3 in terms of abs. adsorption, potentially surpassing the DOE target by ∼10%. The neutron diffraction expts. clearly reveal that the primary CH4 adsorption occurs directly on the open metal sites. Initial 1st-principles calcns. show that the binding energies of CH4 on the open metal sites are significantly higher than those on typical adsorption sites in classical MOFs, consistent with the measured large heats of methane adsorption for these materials. The authors attribute the enhancement of the binding strength to the unscreened electrostatic interaction between CH4 and the coordinatively unsatd. metal ions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXjtFKgsrg%253D&md5=bbaa39565acdc107771ad9c10a7275c6
      30. 30
        Sillar, K.; Sauer, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 18354
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Ab Initio Prediction of Adsorption Isotherms for Small Molecules in Metal-Organic Frameworks: The Effect of Lateral Interactions for Methane/CPO-27-Mg
        Sillar, Kaido; Sauer, Joachim
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (44), 18354-18365CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A hybrid method that combines d. functional theory for periodic structures with wave function-based electron correlation methods for finite-size models of adsorption sites is employed to calc. energies for adsorption of CH4 onto different sites in the metal-org. framework (MOF) CPO-27-Mg (Mg-MOF-74) with chem. accuracy. The adsorption energies for the Mg2+, linker, second layer sites are -27.8, -18.3, and -15.1 kJ/mol. Adsorbate-adsorbate interactions increase the av. CH4 adsorption energy by about 10% (2.4 kJ/mol). The free rotor-harmonic oscillator-ideal gas model is applied to calc. free energies/equil. consts. for adsorption on the individual sites. This information is used in a multisite Langmuir model, augmented with a Bragg-Williams model for latera l interactions, to calc. adsorption isotherms. This ab initio approach yields the contributions of the individual sites to the final isotherms and also of the lateral interactions that contribute about 15% to the max. excess adsorption capacity. Isotherms are calcd. for both abs. amts., for calcn. of isosteric heats of adsorption as function of coverage, and excess amts., for comparison with measured isotherms. Agreement with obsd. excess isotherms is reached if the exptl. detd. limited accessibility of adsorption sites (78%) is taken into account.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhtlekt73O&md5=81f7f5871d800575baaea3dbc520598b
      31. 31
        Chen, L. J.; Grajciar, L.; Nachtigall, P.; Duren, T. J. Phys. Chem. C 2011, 115, 23074
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31
        Accurate Prediction of Methane Adsorption in a Metal-Organic Framework with Unsaturated Metal Sites by Direct Implementation of an ab Initio Derived Potential Energy Surface in GCMC Simulation
        Chen, Linjiang; Grajciar, Lukas; Nachtigall, Petr; Duren, Tina
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2011), 115 (46), 23074-23080CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Whereas grand-canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations based on generic force fields provide good predictions of adsorption isotherms in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), esp. at higher temp., they fail to correctly describe the adsorption mechanism in MOFs with coordinatively unsatd. sites (cus's) at low temps., even for nonpolar fluids such as methane. To address this problem, the authors directly implemented the potential energy surface calcd. by a hybrid DFT/ab inito method in the GCMC simulations using the adsorption of methane on CuBTC as an example. A comparison with previously published in situ expts. shows that the approach not only quant. predicts adsorption isotherms for a wide range of temps. and pressures but also provides the correct description of the adsorption mechanism, including adsorption on the cus's. Also care must be taken when selecting the ab initio method to be coupled with GCMC simulations to obtain accurate predictions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlaqsLfP&md5=a88569f6e2ac033eb30e293bf12d6db9

        Chui, S. S.-Y.; Lo, S. M.-F.; Charmant, J. P. H.; Orpen, A. G.; Willaims, I. D. Science 1999, 283, 1148
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32
        A chemically functionalizable nanoporous material [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n
        Chui, Stephen S.-Y.; Lo, Samuel M.-F.; Charmant, Jonathan P. H.; Orpen, A. Guy; Williams, Ian D.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1999), 283 (5405), 1148-1150CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Although zeolites and related materials combine nanoporosity with high thermal stability, they are difficult to modify or derivatize in a systematic way. A highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) was formed in 80% yield. It has interconnected [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (R is an arom. ring), which create a three-dimensional system of channels with a pore size of 1 nm and an accessible porosity of ∼40% in the solid. Unlike zeolites, the channel linings can be chem. functionalized; for example, the aqua ligands can be replaced by pyridines. TGA and high-temp. single-crystal diffractometry indicate that the framework is stable up to 240°.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXhsFeitLc%253D&md5=8f6f372b015fa0e2bbb7e8bfd316b663

        Lin, X.; Blake, A. J.; Wilson, C.; Sun, X. Z.; Champness, N. R.; George, M. W.; Hubberstey, P.; Mokaya, R.; Schroder, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 10745
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        A Porous Framework Polymer Based on a Zinc(II) 4,4'-Bipyridine-2,6,2',6'-tetracarboxylate: Synthesis, Structure, and "Zeolite-Like" Behaviors
        Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Wilson, Claire; Sun, Xue Zhong; Champness, Neil R.; George, Michael W.; Hubberstey, Peter; Mokaya, Robert; Schroeder, Martin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (33), 10745-10753CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The robust metal-org. framework compd. {[Zn2(L)]·4H2O}∞ (I) was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction of ZnCl2 and 4,4'-bipyridine-2,6,2',6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4L). Compd. I crystallizes in a chiral space group, P42212, with the chirality generated by the helical chains of H-bonded guest H2O mols. rather than by the coordination framework. Removal of guest H2O mols. from the crystal affords the porous material, [Zn2(L)]∞ (II), which has very high thermal stability and is chem. inert. The N2 isotherm of II at 77 K suggests a uniform porous structure with a BET surface area of 312.7 m2/g and a remarkably strong interaction with N2 mols. (βE0 = 29.6 kJ mol-1). II also exhibits significant gas storage capacities of 1.08% for H2 at 4 bar and 77 K and 3.14% (44.0 cm3/g, 67 vol./vol.) for methane at 9 bar at 298 K. The adsorption behavior of II toward org. solvent vapors also was studied, and isotherms reveal that for different solvent vapors adsorption is dominated by two types of processes, absorbate-absorbate or absorbate-absorbent interactions. The adsorption and desorption kinetic processes in II are detd. mainly by the mol. size of the guest species and their interaction with the host.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XnsF2hu7g%253D&md5=814ce41c31d52c3157a64dacc7681a50

        Lin, X.; Telepeni, I.; Blake, A. J.; Dailly, A.; Brown, C. M.; Simmons, J. M.; Zoppi, M.; Walker, G. S.; Thomas, K. M.; Mays, T. J.; Hubberstey, P.; Champness, N. R.; Schroder, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 2159
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34
        High Capacity Hydrogen Adsorption in Cu(II) Tetracarboxylate Framework Materials: The Role of Pore Size, Ligand Functionalization, and Exposed Metal Sites
        Lin, Xiang; Telepeni, Irvin; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Brown, Craig M.; Simmons, Jason M.; Zoppi, Marco; Walker, Gavin S.; Thomas, K. Mark; Mays, Timothy J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (6), 2159-2171CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Isostructural metal-org. framework polymers [Cu2(L)(H2O)2] (L = tetracarboxylate ligands), denoted NOTT-nnn, were synthesized and characterized. Single crystal x-ray structures confirm the complexes to contain binuclear Cu(II) paddlewheel nodes each bridged by four carboxylate centers to give a NbO-type network of 64·82 topol. These complexes are activated by solvent exchange with acetone coupled to heating cycles under vacuum to afford the desolvated porous materials NOTT-100 to NOTT-109. These incorporate a vacant coordination site at each Cu(II) center and have large pore vols. that contribute to the obsd. high H2 adsorption. Indeed, NOTT-103 at 77 K and 60 bar shows a very high total H2 adsorption of 77.8 mg g-1 equiv. to 7.78% [wt% = (wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material)] or 7.22% [wt% = 100(wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material + wt. of adsorbed H2)]. Neutron powder diffraction studies on NOTT-101 reveal three adsorption sites for this material: at the exposed Cu(II) coordination site, at the pocket formed by three {Cu2} paddle wheels, and at the cusp of three Ph rings. Systematic virial anal. of the H2 isotherms suggests that the H2 binding energies at these sites are very similar and the differences are smaller than 1.0 kJ mol-1, although the adsorption enthalpies for H2 at the exposed Cu(II) site are significantly affected by pore metrics. Introducing Me groups or using kinked ligands to create smaller pores can enhance the isosteric heat of adsorption and improve H2 adsorption. However, although increasing the overlap of potential energy fields of pore walls increases the heat of H2 adsorption at low pressure, it may be detrimental to the overall adsorption capacity by reducing the pore vol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXptlOitQ%253D%253D&md5=cbc9f02158801ff5dacb7df033416d78

        A new MOF-505 analog exhibiting high acetylene storage
        Hu, Yunxia; Xiang, Shengchang; Zhang, Wenwei; Zhang, Zhuxiu; Wang, Lei; Bai, Junfeng; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2009), (48), 7551-7553CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new microporous metal-org. framework [Cu2(EBTC)(H2O)2]·8H2O·DMF·DMSO (1; EBTC = diphenylethyne-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylate) was rationally designed with a NbO net. Methanol exchanged MOF 1 was activated overnight at 120° to give anhyd. MOF 1a. The gas sorption isotherms were detd. for MOF 1a with N2, H2, CO2, CH4, and C2H4. MOF 1a exhibits significantly high acetylene storage of 252 and 160 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 295 K under 1 bar, resp.

        Nugent, P.; Belmabkhout, Y.; Burd, S. D.; Cairns, A. J.; Luebke, R.; Forrest, K.; Pham, T.; Ma, S. Q.; Space, B.; Wojtas, L.; Eddaoudi, M.; Zaworotko, M. J. Nature 2013, 495, 80

        Porous materials with optimal adsorption thermodynamics and kinetics for CO2 separation
        Nugent, Patrick; Belmabkhout, Youssef; Burd, Stephen D.; Cairns, Amy J.; Luebke, Ryan; Forrest, Katherine; Pham, Tony; Ma, Shengqian; Space, Brian; Wojtas, Lukasz; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2013), 495 (7439), 80-84CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Energy costs assocd. with the sepn. and purifn. of industrial commodities (e.g., gases, fine chems., fresh water) currently represent ∼15% of global energy prodn.; the demand for such commodities is projected to triple by 2050 (P. Taylor, 2010). The challenge of developing effective sepn. and purifn. technologies which have much smaller energy footprints is greater for CO2 than for other gases; in addn. to its involvement in climate change, CO2 is an impurity in natural gas, biogas (biomass-based natural gas), syngas (CO/H2, the main H2 source for refineries), and many other gas streams. In the context of porous cryst. materials which can exploit equil. and kinetic selectivity, size selectivity and targeted mol. recognition are attractive characteristics for CO2 sepn. and capture, as exemplified by 5A and 13X zeolites (J. Merel, et al., 2008), and metal-org. materials (MOM). This paper reports that a crystal engineering or reticular chem. strategy which controls pore functionality and pore size in a series of MOM with coordinately satd. metal centers and periodically arrayed hexafluorosilicate anions (SiF52-) enables a kinetics and thermodn. sweet spots offering high volumetric uptake at low CO2 partial pressure (<0.15 bar). Most importantly, such MOM offer an unprecedented CO2 sorption selectivity over N2, H2, and CH4, even in the presence of moisture. Thus, these MOM are relevant to CO2 sepn. in the context of post-combustion (flue gas, CO2/N2), pre-combustion (shifted synthesis gas stream, CO2/H2), and natural gas upgrading (natural gas clean-up, CO2/CH4).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjsFCntbg%253D&md5=56941673abb6b13f920476a593dfeb98
      37. 37
        Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        A new equation of state for carbon dioxide covering the fluid region from the triple-point temperature to 1100 K at pressures up to 800 MPa
        Span, R.; Wagner, W.
        Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data (1996), 25 (6), 1509-1596CODEN: JPCRBU; ISSN:0047-2689. (American Chemical Society)
        This work reviews the available data on thermodn. properties of carbon dioxide and presents a new equation of state in the form of a fundamental equation explicit in the Helmholtz free energy. The function for the residual part of the Helmholtz free energy was fitted to selected data of the following properties: (a) thermal properties of the single-phase region (pρT) and (b) of the liq.-vapor satn. curve (ps, ρ', ρ") including the Maxwell criterion, (c) speed of sound w and (d) specific isobaric heat capacity cp of the single phase region and of the satn. curve, (e) specific isochoric heat capacity cυ, (f) specific enthalpy h, (g) specific internal energy u, and (h) Joule-Thomson coeff. μ. By applying modern strategies for the optimization of the math. form of the equation of state and for the simultaneous nonlinear fit to the data of all these properties, the resulting formulation is able to represent even the most accurate data to within their exptl. uncertainty. In the tech. most important region up to pressures of 30 MPa and up to temps. of 523 K, the estd. uncertainty of the equation ranges from ±0.03% to ±0.05% in the d., ±0.03% to ±1% in the speed of sound, and ±0.15% to ±1.5% in the isobaric heat capacity. Special interest has been focused on the description of the crit. region and the extrapolation behavior of the formulation. Without a complex coupling to a scaled equation of state, the new formulation yields a reasonable description even of the caloric properties in the immediate vicinity of the crit. point. At least for the basic properties such as pressure, fugacity, and enthalpy, the equation can be extrapolated up to the limits of the chem. stability of carbon dioxide. Independent equations for the vapor pressure and for the pressure on the sublimation and melting curve, for the satd. liq. and vapor densities, and for the isobaric ideal gas heat capacity are also included. Property tables calcd. from the equation of state are given in the appendix.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XnsFGrsb8%253D&md5=c21e1699c01a87c926394e1cf0b49065

This equation of state corresponds to the new international temp. scale, ITS-90, and can be used to calc. the basic thermal and thermodn. data of methane; it can extrapolate up to 20,000 MPa.

        High H2 adsorption by coordination-framework materials
        Lin, Xiang; Jia, Junhua; Zhao, Xuebo; Thomas, K. Mark; Blake, Alexander J.; Walker, Gavin S.; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin

        Three coordination frameworks with different pore sizes were prepd. from CuII salt and carboxylate ligands of various lengths.         44
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen on metal-organic framework materials for storage applications: comparison with other nanoporous materials
        Thomas, K. Mark
        Dalton Transactions (2009), (9), 1487-1505CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. H adsorption on porous materials is proposed for H storage for transport applications. High pressure exptl. studies of a range of porous materials have obtained max. H excess capacities of 6-8% at 77 K for metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and porous C materials. Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation studies indicate that higher H capacities are possible for covalent org. frameworks (COFs). Currently, the max. isosteric enthalpies of adsorption of ∼13 kJ/mol at 77 K were obsd. for metal-org. framework materials and this is higher than for COFs, where the max. predicted from GCMC simulations is ∼8 kJ/mol. Metal-org. framework materials have structural diversity and scope for modification of surface chem. to enhance H surface interactions. The synthesis of MOFs with stronger H2-surface interactions to give similar H capacities at much higher temps. than 77 K is required and eventually, materials that have these high capacities at ambient temps. with rapid adsorption/desorption characteristics are necessary for applications as H storage materials for transport applications. The current methods envisaged for increasing adsorption at higher temps. involve modification of the surface chem., in particular, the inclusion of open metal centers to increase H surface site interactions, and use of the framework flexibility are also discussed.

        Thermodynamics of the high temperature adsorption of permanent gases by porous carbons
        Cole, John H.; Everett, Douglas H.; Marshall, Charles T.; Ruiz Paniego, A.; Powl, John C.; Rodriguez-Reinoso, Francisco
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 1: Physical Chemistry in Condensed Phases (1974), 70 (12), 2154-69CODEN: JCFTAR; ISSN:0300-9599.
        Studies were made at temps. higher than those commonly used. The adsorption (na) of N, H, Ne, Kr, Ar, and Xe on 2 unactivated and 2 activated Saran-type porous carbons at 0-125° and <1 atm was studied and the data analyzed with the virial expansions of na/p as a function of P and ln(na/p) as a function of na. The no. of terms required for each equation was detd. at each temp. by statistical anal. The latter expansion required fewer terms than the former but the Henry's Law consts. obtained from both agreed. The differential enthalpies and std. differential entropies of adsorption in the limit of ideal behavior were calcd. from the temp. dependence of the Henry's Law consts. The activated carbons had lower Henry's Law consts. and lower adsorption enthalpies whereas the std. entropy increased with activation, indicating the larger free volume available to the absorbed mols. This volume may be estd. by the increase in micropore vol. or the increase in the monolayer equiv. surface area.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2MXhtVelsr0%253D&md5=616c4b6505b7df840381109f9079bdf1

        Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M. Langmuir 1999, 15, 3206
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        47
        Adsorption of Gases on a Carbon Molecular Sieve Used for Air Separation: Linear Adsorptives as Probes for Kinetic Selectivity
        Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M.
        Langmuir (1999), 15 (9), 3206-3218CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption of oxygen, nitrogen, and a series of gases/vapors with linear structures (carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, acetylene and carbon disulfide) on a carbon mol. sieve typical of the materials used for air sepn. were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn. The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) were typically 25 for the carbon mol. sieve used thereby demonstrating the mol. sieving characteristics. The adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for most of the gases and exptl. conditions studied. However there were deviations from the LDF model for carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. In the case of the former, the kinetic models ranged from LDF through a combined barrier resistance/diffusion model to Fickian diffusion depending on the exptl. conditions. The adsorption rate consts. increase exponentially with increasing surface coverage for the mols. which follow the LDF model. The barrier resistance kinetic consts. derived from the combined barrier resistance/diffusion model also have an exponential dependence on surface coverage. The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXitVags7k%253D&md5=05483b1753869f8ee0dc743fbc200391

        Gibbsian Surface Excess for Gas Adsorption-Revisited
        Sircar, S.
        Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (1999), 38 (10), 3670-3682CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
        The Gibbsian surface excess (GSE) represents the true exptl. variable for measuring pure and multicomponent gas adsorption equil. and kinetics by all conventional adsorption methods (volumetric, gravimetric, chromatog., column dynamic, total desorption, isotope exchange, etc). The GSE can be used as primary variables to formulate the general thermodn. and kinetic models for adsorption on energetically homogeneous and heterogeneous adsorbents. Thus, practical thermodn. properties like surface potentials, isosteric heats of adsorption of components, and heat capacities of adsorption systems can be estd. by using GSE. Several thermodn. consistency tests (differential and integral) for binary adsorption systems can also be formulated by using GSE. A math. framework describing the isothermal and nonisothermal column dynamics for adsorption of multicomponent gas mixts. can be developed by using GSE. It can be used to simulate practical process design models (pressure and thermal swing adsorption) for gas mixt. sepn. and purifn. There is no need to est. actual amts. adsorbed from the measured GSE variables by making ambiguous assumptions about the size of the adsorbed phase. The exptl. GSE can be used to completely describe all practical thermodn., kinetic, column dynamic, and process design aspects of gas adsorption technol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXlt1Wju7o%253D&md5=a949c99339cc3dfab7d030e3811adfc5
      49. 49
        Myers, A. L.; Monson, P. A. Adsorpt.—J. Int. Adsorpt. Soc. 2014, 20, 591
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      50. 50
        Yang, S. H.; Lin, X.; Lewis, W.; Suyetin, M.; Bichoutskaia, E.; Parker, J. E.; Tang, C. C.; Allan, D. R.; Rizkallah, P. J.; Hubberstey, P.; Champness, N. R.; Thomas, K. M.; Blake, A. J.; Schroder, M. Nat. Mater. 2012, 11, 710
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        A partially inter-penetrated metal-organic framework for selective hysteretic sorption of carbon dioxide
        Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Lewis, William; Suyetin, Mikhail; Bichoutskaia, Elena; Parker, Julia E.; Tang, Chiu C.; Allan, David R.; Rizkallah, Pierre J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Thomas, K. Mark; Blake, Alexander J.; Schroeder, Martin
        Nature Materials (2012), 11 (8), 710-716CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Selective CO2 capture in porous materials has potential for the storage and treatment of fuel and flue gases; however, adsorption capacities under dynamic conditions are often insufficient for practical applications and strategies to enhance CO2-host selectivity are required. The unique, partially inter-penetrated metal-org. framework, NOTT-202, represents a new class of dynamic material which undergoes pronounced framework phase transition on desolvation. This work reports temp.-dependent adsorption/desorption hysteresis in de-solvated NOTT-202a which selectively responds to CO2. The CO2 isotherm shows 3 steps in the adsorption profile at 195° K; step-wise filling of pores generated within the obsd. partially inter-penetrated structure has been modeled using grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations. Adsorption of N2, CH4, O2, Ar, and H2 exhibited reversible isotherms without hysteresis under the same conditions, allowing for gas capture at high pressure; but, it selectively leaves CO2 trapped in nano-pores at low pressure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XnvVyrs7c%253D&md5=cfc77f36f485f714a2755627b6e6d7e9

        Llewellyn, Philip L.; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Serre, Christian; Vimont, Alexandre; Daturi, Marco; Hamon, Lomig; De Weireld, Guy; Chang, Jong-San; Hong, Do-Young; Hwang, Young Kyu; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Ferey, Gerard
        Langmuir (2008), 24 (14), 7245-7250CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        Mesoporous MOFs MIL-100 and MIL-101 adsorb huge amts. of CO2 and CH4. Characterization was performed using both manometry and gravimetry in different labs. for isotherms coupled with microcalorimetry and FTIR to specify the gas-solid interactions. In particular, the uptake of CO2 in MIL-101 occurs with a record capacity of 40 mmol g-1 or 390 cm3STP cm-3 at 5 MPa and 303 K.

        Rexer, T. F. T.; Benham, M. J.; Aplin, A. C.; Thomas, K. M. Energy Fuels 2013, 27, 3099
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Methane Adsorption on Shale under Simulated Geological Temperature and Pressure Conditions
        Rexer, Thomas F. T.; Benham, Michael J.; Aplin, Andrew C.; Thomas, K. Mark
        Energy & Fuels (2013), 27 (6), 3099-3109CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
        Shale gas is becoming an increasingly important energy resource. In this study, the adsorption of methane on a dry, org.-rich Alum shale sample was studied at pressures up to ∼14 MPa and temps. in the range 300-473 K, which are relevant to gas storage under geol. conditions. Maximum methane excess uptake was 0.176-0.042 mmol g-1 (125-30 scf t-1) for the temp. range of 300-473 K. The decrease in max. methane surface excess with increasing temp. can be described with a linear model. An isosteric enthalpy of adsorption 19.2 ± 0.1 kJ mol-1 was detd. at 0.025 mmol g-1 using the van't Hoff equation. Supercrit. adsorption was modeled using the modified Dubinin-Radushkevich and the Langmuir equations. The results are compared with abs. isotherms calcd. from surface excess and the pore vols. obtained from subcrit. gas adsorption (nitrogen (78 K), carbon dioxide (273 and 195 K), and CH4 (112 K)). The subcrit. adsorption and the surface excess results allow an upper limit to be put on the amt. of gas that can be retained by adsorption during gas generation from petroleum source rocks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnsVWju7Y%253D&md5=abb1f04a6833e8d0aed60abd2ead7278

        Adsorption equations. A review of the literature
        Swan, Enoch; Urquhart, A. R.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry (1927), 31 (), 251-76CODEN: JPCHAX; ISSN:0022-3654.
        All the various equations that have been proposed to represent adsorption phenomena are collected and their applicability to actual adsorption systems is discussed. The headings are: General Adsorption Equation, Isotherm, Isobar, Isostere, Rate of Adsorption, Heal of Adsorption and Conclusion. A bibliography of 117 references is included.

        54
        General theory of sorption phenomena
        Iliin, B.
        (1923), 107 (), 145-53 ISSN:.
        Equations have been derived which agree well with exptl. data. An equation in the form for that of a monomol. reaction showed why c∼ is not equal to a, where c∼ is the amt. absorbed when t= ∞, called the sorption capacity, and a is a const. The sorption isotherm was given by c∼ = cmax. (1 - e -ωp), where p is the pressure and ω is a const. The correction introduced because the sorption capacity was not const. under all conditions increased the no. of sorption processes which could be expressed by c = c∼(l-e-kt). The dependence of the sorption capacity upon temp. was expressed by c∼ = c0e-δ√T. The crossing of curves at different points was explained by the fact that the initial sorption velocity can increase with temp. while c∼ always decreases.

        How hydration drastically improves adsorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 in the flexible chromium terephthalate MIL-53
        Llewellyn, Philip L.; Bourrrelly, Sandrine; Serre, Christian; Filinchuk, Yaroslav; Ferey, Gerard

        The hydrated form of the microporous metal org. framework MIL-53(Cr) performs better than the dehydrated form for the selectivity binding of carbon dioxide over methane.         Banerjee, R.; Furukawa, H.; Britt, D.; Knobler, C.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 3875

        56
        Control of Pore Size and Functionality in Isoreticular Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks and their Carbon Dioxide Selective Capture Properties
        Banerjee, Rahul; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Britt, David; Knobler, Carolyn; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (11), 3875-3877CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new cryst. zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), ZIF-78 to -82, were prepd. from zinc(II) nitrate and mixts. of 2-nitroimidazole and five different functionalized imidazoles and were found to have the GME topol. These structures, along with three previously reported GME ZIFs, constitute a series of highly porous materials with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller surface areas ranging from 620 to 1730 m2/g. The pore diams. and apertures vary incrementally from 7.1 to 15.9 Å and 3.8 to 13.1 Å, resp., and the functionalities decorating the pores vary from polar cyano- and nitro- groups to nonpolar alkyl groups. The variability expressed in these materials makes them highly attractive for study as gas-sepn. media. Selectivity values calcd. for sepn. of CO2 and CH4 predict that the ZIFs with polar functionality, ZIF-78 (10.6:1) and -82 (9.6:1), retain CO2 gas to a greater degree than the other members of the GME series and BPL-activated carbon. These predictions are borne out in dynamic breakthrough studies, which confirm the increased capacity of ZIF-78 and -82 and demonstrate the promise of this class of materials.

        Du, L. T.; Lu, Z. Y.; Zheng, K. Y.; Wang, J. Y.; Zheng, X.; Pan, Y.; You, X. Z.; Bai, J. F. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 562
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        61
        Fine-Tuning Pore Size by Shifting Coordination Sites of Ligands and Surface Polarization of Metal-Organic Frameworks To Sharply Enhance the Selectivity for CO2
        Du, Liting; Lu, Zhiyong; Zheng, Kaiyuan; Wang, Junyi; Zheng, Xin; Pan, Yi; You, Xiaozeng; Bai, Junfeng
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (2), 562-565CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Based upon the (3,6)-connected metal-org. framework {Cu(L1)·2H2O·1.5DMF}∞ (L1 = 5-(pyridin-4-yl)isophthalic acid) (SYSU, for Sun Yat-Sen University), iso-reticular {Cu(L2)·DMF}∞ (L2 = 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai7; NJU-Bai for Nanjing University Bai group) and {Cu(L3)·DMF·H2O}∞ (L3 = 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai8) were designed by shifting the coordination sites of ligands to fine-tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated N atoms, resp., with almost no changes in surface area or porosity. Compared with those of the prototype SYSU, both the adsorption enthalpy and selectivity of CO2 for NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 have been greatly enhanced, which makes NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 good candidates for postcombustion CO2 capture. Notably, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy of NJU-Bai7 is the highest reported so far among the MOFs without any polarizing functional groups or open metal sites. Meanwhile, NJU-Bai8 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and good CO2/CH4 selectivity at high pressure, which are quite valuable characteristics in the purifn. of natural gases.

      63. 63
        Webster, C. E.; Drago, R. S.; Zerner, M. C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998, 120, 5509
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        63
        Molecular Dimensions for Adsorptives
        Webster, Charles Edwin; Drago, Russell S.; Zerner, Michael C.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (22), 5509-5516CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Pore vols., accessible surface areas, and the thermodn. of adsorption are essential in the understanding of solid surface characteristics fundamental to catalyst and adsorbent screening and selection. The recently developed Multiple Equil. Anal. (MEA) provides a thorough characterization of the adsorption process. Mol. properties such as mol. vols. and projected mol. areas are needed in order to convert moles adsorbed to surface vols. and probe dependent, accessible surface areas. These mol. quantities are also needed in conventional methods for detg. areas and pore vols. Generally, these mol. properties have been estd. from bulk properties, but many assumptions are required. As a result, different literature values are employed for these essential mol. properties. In this article, mol. structures for various conformers of many mols. are calcd. using ZINDO. Mol. vols. and excluded mol. areas are detd. from these structures and tabulated for a variety of mols. Mol. dimensions of mols. are another important consideration needed to understand mol. exclusion as well as size and shape selectivity. Mol. dimensions along the symmetry axes are tabulated as well as the two smallest min. dimensions of each mol. Examples are presented to illustrate the use of these quantities in shape and size selectivity, mol. exclusion, diffusion, and adsorbent selection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Ainscough, A. N.; Dollimore, D. Langmuir 1987, 3, 708
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        64
        Adsorption capacity of molecular sieve type carbons
        Ainscough, A. N.; Dollimore, David
        Langmuir (1987), 3 (5), 708-13CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463.
        The prepn. of carbons from polymeric sourcds, such as ethylcellulose, poly(acrylonitrile), cellulose, PVC, and poly(furfuryl alc.), is described. All of these carbons showed varying degrees of adsorptive capacity. A prepn. of carbons from polymeric sources, such as ethylcellulose, poly(acrylonitrile), cellulose, PVC, and poly(furfuryl alc.), is described. All of these carbons showed varying degrees of adsorptive capacity. A prepn. of a composite carbon based on a com. active carbon is described. Viscose carbons reported in an earlier publication are studied further. The adsorption isotherms on these carbons for the following adsorbates are reported (K): (77.4), CO2 (194.7), CO (77), H2O (298.5), N2O (194.7), Ar (77.4), CH4 (90.2), C2H6 (194.7), C3H8 (194.7), C4H10 (273.2), cyclopropane (194.7), CCl4 (298.2), C6H6 (298.2), α-pinene (298.2), and neopentane (273.2). These are mainly type I adsorption isotherms. The apparent pore vol. as detd. from the uptake of these adsorbates at P/Pσ = 0.95 shows that some of these carbons showed selectivity based on adsorbate mol. size while others, while still showing large apparent pore vols., showed no selectivity of this kind. These isotherms are analyzed by methods based on the BET and Dubinin theories. In particular, a relation between the BET C value and the Dubinin D value is noted, based on the fact that the adsorption isotherms are amenable to analyses by both methods. It is concluded that the following parameters contribute to the selectivity that carbons show to adsorbate capacity: (1) adsorbate mol. size; (2) temp. of the adsorption isotherm; (3) shape of the adsorbate mols.; (4) prior adsorption of water vapor.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2sXlsVajs7g%253D&md5=85bdfb58b898f5b8839d973bfded2435

        Theory of chromatography; the influence of incomplete equilibrium on the front boundary of chromatograms and on the effectiveness of separation
        GLUECKAUF E; COATES J I
        Journal of the Chemical Society (1947), (), 1315-21 ISSN:0368-1769.
        There is no expanded citation for this reference.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaH2s%252FjtlKnsQ%253D%253D&md5=2665f70d2ab09a304c61abb67d5e5c66
      66. 66
        Glueckauf, E. Trans. Faraday Soc. 1955, 51, 1540
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Theory of chromatography. X. Formulas for diffusion into spheres and their application to chromatography
        Glueckauf, E.
        Transactions of the Faraday Society (1955), 51 (), 1540-51CODEN: TFSOA4; ISSN:0014-7672.
        cf. C.A. 49, 11326f. Various empirical diffusion equations were tested by giving the rate of the mean internal concn. change d‾q/dt as a function of the mean internal concn. ‾q and the surface concn. q. Under the conditions occurring in chromatographic columns with substances following linear or moderately curved adsorption or exchange isotherms (Kd, distribution coeff. <3) where conditions were maintained close to equil., equation I was almost perfect, II fully adequate: d‾q/dt = (π2D/r2)(q-‾q) + [1-(π2/15)](dq/dt) (I) = (15D/r2)(q-‾q) (II), where D (sq.cm./sec.) = diffusion coeff. into sphere of radius r(cm.). When applied to the practical chromatographic break-through curves, the difference between the equations, except for irreversible exchange, did not warrant the use of equations more complex than II.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG28XlvV2ksg%253D%253D&md5=8cc1cd22650e5e4ddd8a2fcd3de74b99
      67. 67
        Loughlin, K. F.; Hassan, M. M.; Fatehi, A. I.; Zahur, M. Gas Sep. Purif. 1993, 7, 264
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Rate and equilibrium sorption parameters for nitrogen and methane on carbon molecular sieve
        Loughlin, K. F.; Hassan, M. M.; Fatehi, A. I.; Zahur, M.
        Gas Separation & Purification (1993), 7 (4), 264-73CODEN: GSEPEP; ISSN:0950-4214.
        Sorption parameters for N and CH4 on carbon mol. sieves (CMS) were obtained by using chromatog., volumetric, and gravimetric techniques. The equil. parameters (Henry consts., heats of adsorption, Langmuir consts.) are consistent with reported literature values. Measurements of adsorption rates by using a volumetric app. give results inconsistent with the diffusion hypothesis. The phenomena can be explained by the presence of a barrier resistance along with a diffusion mechanism. Anal. of results shows that the resistance measured by the chromatog. method is consistent with the resistance of the combined barrier resistance-diffusion model. The latter 2 resistances can only be obtained from the volumetric results. The general equation for additivity of resistances of H. Haynes and P. Sarma (1973) for breakthrough curves on a chromatogram is modified to account for the barrier resistance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXisFChsb8%253D&md5=f5e6e996f0375d1b7c1d412ec3335b96

      69. 69
        Klafter, J.; Shlesinger, M. F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1986, 83, 848
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        69
        On the relationship among three theories of relaxation in disordered systems
        Klafter J; Shlesinger M F
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1986), 83 (4), 848-51 ISSN:0027-8424.
        Empirical evidence has accumulated showing the wide occurrence of a stretched-exponential relaxation decay law for many diverse condensed-matter systems. Several theories based on different physical mechanisms have been successful in deriving the stretched-exponential decay law in a natural way. Three of these theories, the direct-transfer model, the hierarchically constrained dynamics model, and the defect-diffusion model are shown here to have an underlying common mathematical structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3cnivFaktw%253D%253D&md5=675a82758acf65426525b473a6e54982
      70. 70
        Kortunov, P.; Chmelik, C.; Karger, J.; Rakoczy, R. A.; Ruthven, D. M.; Traa, Y.; Vasenkov, S.; Weitkamp, J. Adsorpt.—J. Int. Adsorpt. Soc. 2005, 11, 235
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        70
        Sorption Kinetics and Intracrystalline Diffusion of Methanol in Ferrierite: An Example of Disguised Kinetics
        Kortunov, P.; Chmelik, C.; Kaerger, J.; Rakoczy, R. A.; Ruthven, D. M.; Traa, Y.; Vasenkov, S.; Weitkamp, J.
        Adsorption (2005), 11 (3/4), 235-244CODEN: ADSOFO; ISSN:0929-5607. (Springer)
        Sorption kinetics of MeOH in large crystals of ferrierite were studied in detail by interference microscopy (IFM) and IR microscopy (IRM). The IFM measurements yield the transient concn. profiles, thus providing a direct measurement of both the surface resistance to mass transfer and the internal diffusion resistance. For this system, the uptake rate is controlled by the combined effects of surface resistance and diffusion through the 8-ring channels (in the y-direction). Transport through the 10-ring channels (in the z-direction) appears to be blocked by surface resistance. Although the overall uptake curves conform well to the root t law the diffusivity values derived from the uptake curves vary widely depending on the assumed direction of diffusion. Even if the correct direction of diffusion is assumed, the diffusivity values derived from the uptake curves are seriously in error as a result of the intrusion of surface resistance. The existence of transport resistances at the crystal surface is clearly apparent from the transient concn. profiles but is not obvious from the uptake curves.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XktFyksQ%253D%253D&md5=5d2d2ea2d87223b484027ff6c99846d2

        Forster, T. Z. Naturforsch., A: Phys., Phys. Chem., Kosmophys. 1949, 4, 321

        Palmer, R. G.; Stein, D. L.; Abrahams, E.; Anderson, P. W. Phys. Rev. Lett. 1984, 53, 958

      73. 73
        Glarum, S. H. J. Chem. Phys. 1960, 33, 1371
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        73
        Dielectric relaxation of polar liquids
        Glarum, Sivert H.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1960), 33 (), 1371-5CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        The statistical theory of the dielec. relaxation of polar liquids is developed by using the fluctuation-dissipation approach to linear dissipative phenomena, and an expression is derived relating the complex dielec. const. to a time-dependent microscopic correlation function. A finite no. of microscopic relaxation times leads to an equal no. of macroscopic decay times, and, in the case of a single relaxation time τ0, the decay time is given by T0 = [3 ε0/(2 ε0 + ε∞)]τ0, where ε0 is the static dielec, const. and ε∞ is the high-frequency dielec. const. Relaxation times were also detd. for systems having 2 decay times, and for systems characterized by circular-arc and skewed-arc distribution functions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3MXmt1yjsA%253D%253D&md5=6392929b6e48a507512825460f6ef710
      74. 74
        Bordewijk, P. Chem. Phys. Lett. 1975, 32, 592
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Defect-diffusion models of dielectric relaxation
        Bordewijk, P.
        Chemical Physics Letters (1975), 32 (3), 592-6CODEN: CHPLBC; ISSN:0009-2614.
        Dielec. relaxation due to defect-diffusion in liqs., as introduced by Glarum (1960), is considered for the case that reorientation of a mol. at time t >0 may be due not only to the nearest defect at t = 0, but to any defect in the liq. For 1-dimensional diffusion one then obtains the empirical relaxation function introduced by Williams and Watts (1970) with β = 0.5, and for 3-dimensional diffusion a result only slightly differing from that for a single relaxation time. A model of dielec. relaxation by diffusion of defects only leads to considerable deviations from a single relaxation time when the diffusion is restricted in some way.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2MXks12rt7g%253D&md5=f30c387a821900ddddf7f7073ad46cff
      75. 75
        Shlesinger, M. F.; Montroll, E. W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1984, 81, 1280
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        75
        On the Williams-Watts function of dielectric relaxation
        Shlesinger, Michael F.; Montroll, Elliott W.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1984), 81 (4), 1280-3CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Exptl. frequency-dependent dielec. consts. of broad classes of materials including polymeric systems and glasses may be interpreted in terms of the Williams-Watts polarization decay function .vphi.α(t) = exp[-(t/T)α], 0 < α < 1. The exponent α and the time const. T depend on the material and fixed external conditions such as temp. and pressure. The authors derive this form of .vphi.α(t)from the following random-walk model. Suppose that an elec. field has been applied for some time to a medium contg. many polar mols. (or polar groups in complex mols.) and the direction of their dipole moments remains frozen as the field is removed. Further, suppose that the medium contains mobile defects that on reaching the site of a frozen dipole relax the medium to the degree that the dipole may reorient itself. If the diffusion of defects toward dipoles is executed as a continuous-time random walk composed of an alternation of steps and pauses and the pausing-time distribution function has a long tail of the form ψ(t) .varies. t-1-α, then the relaxation function has the above fractional exponential form.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXhsV2gtbc%253D&md5=3d2960df0db50c248bd23a96d6d628dd
      76. 76
        Fletcher, A. J.; Cussen, E. J.; Bradshaw, D.; Rosseinsky, M. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 9750
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Nanoporous Ni2(4,4'-Bipyridine)3(NO3)4 Metal-Organic Framework Materials Templated with Methanol and Ethanol: Structural Effects in Adsorption Kinetics
        Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Cussen, Edmund J.; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.; Thomas, K. Mark
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (31), 9750-9759CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Desolvation of Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4·2CH3OH and Ni2(4,4'-bipyridine)3(NO3)4·2C2H5OH give flexible metal-org. porous structures M and E, resp., which have the same stoichiometry, but subtly different structures. This study combines measurements of the thermodn. and kinetics of carbon dioxide, methanol, and ethanol sorption on adsorbents M and E over a range of temps. with adsorbent structural characterization at different adsorbate (guest) loadings. The adsorption kinetics for methanol and ethanol adsorption on porous structure E obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for adsorption at low surface coverage. The corresponding adsorption kinetics for porous structure M follow a double exponential (DE) model, which is consistent with two different barriers for diffusion through the windows and along the pores in the structure. The former is a high-energy barrier due to the opening of the windows in the structure, required to allow adsorption to occur, while the latter is a lower-energy barrier for diffusion in the pore cavities. X-ray diffraction studies at various methanol and ethanol loadings showed that the host porous structures E and M underwent different scissoring motions, leading to an increase in unit cell vol. with the space group remaining unchanged during adsorption. The results are discussed in terms of reversible adsorbate/adsorbent (host/guest) structural changes and the adsorption mechanism involving hydrogen-bonding interactions with sp. surface sites for methanol and ethanol adsorption in relation to pore size and extent of filling. This paper contains the first evidence for individual kinetic barriers to diffusion through windows and pore cavities in flexible porous coordination polymer frameworks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXlvVSktrs%253D&md5=8411f5a8659801221ba73a7b0b76df57
      77. 77
        Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. C 2007, 111, 2107
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        Kinetic Isotope Quantum Effects in the Adsorption of H2O and D2O on Porous Carbons
        Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2007), 111 (5), 2107-2115CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        This paper describes a study of the adsorption characteristics of H2O and D2O on 2 activated carbons, BAX950, contg. a range of micro- and mesoporosity, and G209, a predominantly microporous material. Adsorption kinetics of H2O and D2O on activated C BAX950 were studied at 293-313 K and 278-303 K, resp. The adsorption/desorption of H2O and D2O were also studied on activated C G209 at 298 K. The adsorption isotherms for H2O and D2O agree well while greater adsorption hysteresis was obsd. for H2O compared with D2O. Comparison of the adsorption kinetic behavior of H2O and D2O indicated a kinetic isotope effect. The trends in isotherm hysteresis, kinetic parameters, and activation energies are attributed to quantum effects, which are the source of differences in intermol. hydrogen bonding in H2O and D2O adsorbates and bonding between these adsorbates and surface oxygen functional groups. The effects of confinement in pores on adsorbate structure are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXktV2qug%253D%253D&md5=5fb83363787135e860e810925d6423ac

        Fletcher, A. J.; Yuzak, Y.; Thomas, K. M. Carbon 2006, 44, 989
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        Adsorption and desorption kinetics for hydrophilic and hydrophobic vapors on activated carbon
        Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Yuezak, Yaprak; Thomas, K. Mark
        Carbon (2006), 44 (5), 989-1004CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Adsorption dynamics are of fundamental importance in applications of adsorbents in real situations. The adsorption/desorption characteristics of a series of adsorbates, with varying hydrophilic/hydrophobic and structural characteristics, for activated C BAX950, were investigated for temps. in the range 288-323 K. These data provide a comprehensive kinetic study of adsorption/desorption for an activated C. The results are discussed in relation to the adsorbent pore structure and functional group concn., adsorptive structure and adsorption mechanism. The study provides evidence for a compensation effect where activation energy and ln(pre-exponential factor) parameters obtained from the Arrhenius equation exhibit a linear correlation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvVensQ%253D%253D&md5=252f7312623d74ff9bf55dca001fae30

        Bell, J. G.; Zhao, X.; Uygur, Y.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. C 2011, 115, 2776
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Adsorption of Chloroaromatic Models for Dioxins on Porous Carbons: The Influence of Adsorbate Structure and Surface Functional Groups on Surface Interactions and Adsorption Kinetics
        Bell, Jon G.; Zhao, Xuebo; Uygur, Yaprak; Thomas, K. Mark
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2011), 115 (6), 2776-2789CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxin and polychlorinated dibenzofuran species are classes of extremely toxic compds. generated in very low concns. in postcombustion gases and these may be removed by adsorption on porous carbons. Their extreme toxicity and very low volatility prevent detailed study of their adsorption characteristics, and therefore, models for dioxins were used. Chlorobenzene, 2-chlorotoluene, 1,3-dichlorobenzene, and 2-chloroanisole were used as models to study factors influencing the adsorption characteristics of dioxins on porous carbons. Adsorption studies were carried out under conditions of very low concn. and temps. up to 453 K, which simulate those found in dioxin abatement systems. Adsorption of 2-chloroanisole on three carbons with various micro/mesoporous structures showed that microporous structure was a crit. adsorbent characteristic under these conditions. A microporous activated carbon was selected for detailed thermodn. and kinetic studies of adsorption of chloroarom. species in relation to adsorbate structure and adsorbent surface functional groups. Virial equation anal. of adsorption isotherms was used to det. the Henry's Law consts. and isosteric enthalpies of adsorption at zero surface coverage to compare adsorbate-adsorbent interactions. The van't Hoff equation was used to det. the enthalpy of adsorption as a function of surface coverage. The role of surface functional groups on adsorption thermodn. was studied by oxidizing and reducing the carbon in nitric acid and hydrogen, resp. The important factor influencing adsorption at very low concns. is the adsorbate adsorbent interaction. Oxidn. of the carbon adsorbent only has a small effect on the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. The adsorption kinetics for each isotherm pressure increment were described by the stretched exponential equation. The activation energies and enthalpies of activation were calcd. as a function of surface coverage for adsorption kinetics of chloroarom. species. The planar mols. studied had lower activation energies and enthalpies of activation than isosteric enthalpy of adsorption indicating that a site-to-site surface hopping mechanism is the main factor in detg. the adsorption kinetics. In comparison, 2-chloroanisole is nonplanar with a methoxy group giving rise to a larger min. cross-section size and higher barrier to diffusion than isosteric enthalpy of adsorption at low surface coverage leading to the adsorption kinetics being mainly detd. by diffusion through constrictions in the porous structure under these conditions. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption initially increase with increasing surface coverage and this is attributed to π-π interactions of planar arom. mols. confined in microporosity. The trends in the kinetic barriers and isosteric enthalpies of adsorption with surface coverage for 2-chlorotoluene are similar irresp. of adsorbent oxidn./redn., indicating that surface functional groups only have a relatively small effect on adsorption characteristics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1egurc%253D&md5=6d300db5104b9b0fad7b84271bdcb133

        Zhao, X.; Villar-Rodil, S.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. B 2006, 110, 9947
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        80
        Kinetic Isotope Effect for H2 and D2 Quantum Molecular Sieving in Adsorption/Desorption on Porous Carbon Materials
        Zhao, Xuebo; Villar-Rodil, Silvia; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2006), 110 (20), 9947-9955CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
        Adsorption and desorption of H2 and D2 from porous C materials, such as activated C at 77 K, are usually fully reversible with very rapid adsorption/desorption kinetics. The adsorption and desorption of H2 and D2 at 77 K on a C mol. sieve (Takeda 3A), where the kinetic selectivity was incorporated by C deposition, and a C, where the pore structure was modified by thermal annealing to give similar pore structure characteristics to the C mol. sieve substrate, were studied. The D2 adsorption and desorption kinetics were significantly faster (up to ×1.9) than the corresponding H2 kinetics for specific pressure increments/decrements. This represents the 1st exptl. observation of kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving in porous materials due to the larger zero-point energy for the lighter H2, resulting in slower adsorption/desorption kinetics compared with the heavier D2. The results are discussed in terms of the adsorption mechanism.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XktVertbw%253D&md5=08b52fe90cfa35318807cca2a2935675
